Opaque black color, small brown head. Strong chocolaty-cocoa aroma, almost chocolate pudding like. Very intensive. But I liked aroma more: the flavor has lactose, sweet milk chocolate and cocoa. Palate is rounded like in the most oatmeal stouts. Finish has some burnt/roasted notes.

Bottled at OHaras, Tampere. Black with dark brown head. Thick roasty and coffeish aroma with alcohol, licorice and hint of dark fruits. Coffee, charcoal, fruity hops, dark fruits and licorice in the flavor. Grainy and whiskeyish finish. Smooth oily palate. Quite tasty although I liked the reserve special better.
tasting on 3/6/10.  dark pour with tan head... sweet roasted malts with some light chocolate notes... nutty, malty aroma... nice roasted finish.

Bottled. The aroma has roasted coffee malts and some moccha. Black coloured beer with a thin, off-white head. The taste has roasted coffe again, some sweetness and bitterness. Medium bodied and very well balanced. Nice beer.
Dark brown with a red hue and a very low brown head. Nice chocolate aroma with further notes of caffe latte, wood and roasted malts. Moderate sweet aroma with a tinglish bitterness. Medium body.

Ho boy, this is one tasty beer. Poured with smallish burnt sugar colored head that mostly subsided and no lace. Color is an opaque brownish black. Aroma is very rich, roasty, malty, sweet, cocoa, hint of coffee, hints of vanilla, caramel, burnt sugar, and toffee. Flavors about the same also with nut skins, Good body and carbonation. Finish is like flavor and fairly long. Just a hint of alcohol at the end. Very nice beer. Could be a session for slow drinking. Would go great with very rich powerful foods like game, dark meat fowl, and spicey sausages.
This is a decent stout black pour brown head .Taste sweet oatmeal chocolate, coffee, roasty,  finishes smooth with coffe aftertaste

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2016 355ml bottle (Pikkulintu, Helsinki) 2010/02/10 (7:4:7:4:14=3.6)
Big meaty aroma - later more soy sauce. Jet black, no head. Full palate, with pleasant soft carbonation. Not just full, but slick. Huge roasty body - very burnt but not astringent. Covers the alcohol well. However, by the end the slickness becomes too much - its actually slimy, and leaves the mouth feeling slimy, which is not the kind of finish I like.
Rerate: Tap (Riga Craft Beer Festival 2016) (7:4+:7:4:14=3.6+)
Super rich soy roast, a bit bacony - yum! Glad to see theyve kept the quality up and not got lazy.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2015 Bottle. Very dark brown with small tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, caramel and a little liquorice. Flavour is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, medium sweet, little liquorice, hop and medium bitter.

Bottle. Deep black with small tanned head.
Deep coffee, liquorice and wheat aroma.
Lightly bitter flavour with coffee, liquorice, smoke and oak.
Bottle.Black colour with off-beige head.Aroma is rosted of coffee and butnt wood.Flavor is medium sweet with hint of chocolate and tar,nice smooth finish.
Bottle, thanks dEnk! Pours pitch black with a very small tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, caramel and cookies. Bitter coffee flavor, smooth and slightly creamy. Nice.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2010 Quite a roasty, bitter stout with some burnt flavors.  I enjoyed it, however, it did seem just a tad undercarbonated, and, as a result, had a bit of a thin mouthfeel.  Good-not-great stout that Id consider drinking again.

Bottle  Pours a nice black with a tan head.  The head lasts okay and laces well.  Aroma is sweet roast, some alcohol, chocolate, and some coffee.  Has a light carbonation.  The flavor is tasty.  Nice roastness and a hardy stout.  Alcohol hidden well.  Has a syrupy texture.  The body is medium to full.  Has a good finish and a real good aftertaste.  This is a tasty beer.  Very pleasing.
chocolate, coffee, roasty, licorice, black, brown foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, average carbonation, bitter,

From Voldby, DK.
Bottled, 100110.
Black with beige head. Aroma of roasted barley. Flavor with hints of coffee and chocolate.

This beer had a black pour with a coffee colored head sitting on top. Taste is a little oatmeal and slightly roasty but nothing special. Drinkability wasnt great due to the taste not being very enticing. Oh well, I was still glad to have had the chance to drink this midwestern brew.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-26-2007 16:11:15

Bottled. Black coloured. Dense light brown head. ARoma of grass, syrup, light roast, spice and herbs. Flavour  of roast, light sweetness, cocoa, herbs and flowers. Medium to full bodied. Sweet roasty bitterness in the end with a somewhat herbal touch.

12 oz bottle from the Foodery in Philly pours a deep dark reddish brown with a slight ring of foam & no lacing. A great smoked oak and leather aroma is what really stands out with this brew. Also hints of walnut, vanilla, and dark chocolate. Dry, tannic taste of roasty grains. Smooth chewy oat mouthfeel, with a bit of an alcohol bite that lingers in the end.

Pours dark black with a big thick dark brown head. Aroma of roasted malts and a little chocolate and coffee. Taste is medium sweetness and lightly bitter, full body, thick feel, average carbonation. Very Good.

(Bottle at Olutkellari Helsinki) Poured black with small and light brown head. Aroma was soft and contained roastedness and liquorice. Palate was full bodied, soft and dryish with medium carbonation. Flavours were roastedness, chocolate, hint of coffee, hops, ash and bitterenss. Aftertaste was ashy and mildly bitter.

(Bottled) Almost black with a small, beige, quickly fading head. Mild aroma of licorice and lightly roasted malt with a sourish touch. Flavor is quite roasted-malty with the oatmeal smoothness emerging with a slight delay. Next sips are smoother, with licorice clearly present. Almost full body, slightly rough-ashy palate with low carbonation. Basically a nice and smooth oatmeal stout, but somehow it just doesnt feel quite awesome.

12-FEB-2010, bottle @home, from "Fish & Beer".
Black, dark brown but low head. HEAVY!
Very dark roasted, coffee, chocolate and cola.
Very fine hoppy bitterness, and somewhat creamy.
I had Ølfabrikken stout immidiatly afterwards, and that was even more  fat and creamy.
Anyway, very fine porter.

Bottle. High creamy and lasting light brown head. Pitch black body. Roasted malt aroma with coffee and choccolate with a hint of the alcohol. Creamy light bitter coffee choccolate flavor with a low carbonation and a long smooth and pleasant aftertaste. Alcohol level seems just right.
Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Black - brown head. Coffee, chocolate, high malty, roasted, smooth body, oatmeal smoothiness, light sweetness, light hoppy. Very nice.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2010 Bottle.  Pours a deep clear dark black hued brown with a thin dark tan head. Gorgeous roast, soft touches of coffee, chocolate syrup.  Medium bodied, chocolatey, sweet touches of oatmeal. Nice roast on the finish, with a bit of char, almost a hint of toasted marshmallow.  Really well done.  Subtle and tasty.  Update based on a bottle I just had, and forgot Id rated this before.  Notes are pretty similar, bumped it a point on appearance since its a really pretty beer.

Pours completely opaque motor oil w/ a super dense oily peaty head, aroma is strawberries, vanilla, dried fruits, and a touch of floury cake, body is smooth and oily w/ forementioned fruits prominent with the roasted malts hitting at finish, a really unique and enjoyable oatmeal stout

Bottle. Creamy lightbrown fair mostly deminishing head. Pitch black colour. Heavy malty and light hoppy aroma. Exstremely roasted heavy bitter flavor. Some chocolate notes. Unbalanced. Average heavy bitter finish. Oily palate and too fizzy. Not a very good oatmeal stout.

Pours thick and black with a brown head that didnt last long. Bold, roasty aroma with bitter chocolate and faint coffee. The flavor is similar, and sweet, with toasted oats. Has a kinda clean or watery phase near the finish, but does finish with some bitterness and anise. Medium bodied with barely any carbonation.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2015 Bottle. Small head with short duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are milk chocolate, roast malt, coffee, vanilla and hops. Rerated. Tap @ Fermentoren, Aarhus. Nice head with excellent duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are sweet roast malt, chocolate, licorice and hops. Nice dry and smooth. Lovely.

I have been saving this one.  Bottle thanks to bigmmartin.  Aroma is burnt malts, coffee, and a bit of dark chocolate.  I also get some notes of licorice, caramel, and a tiny bit of oats.  A bit chewey, but smooth.  Finishes, dry with a chocolatey after taste.  A very good beer, thanks Mike.

Bottle @ HJ Hansen, Odense. Pours thick black with a small collapsing brown head on top. Mild roast, caramel, vanilla, oat and chocolate. Very smooth. Medium to low carbonation. Alcohol well hidden. Very nice

12 oz. bottle from Belmont Party Supply.  Looks like motor oil coming out of the bottle, a dark, opaque brown that is almost black- but not quite- with a half-inch thick brown head that leaves a nice cap on the beer.  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, raisins, coffee, oats, brown sugar, and a little bit of earthy hops coming through.  The flavor is a bit more roasty and smoky, with chocolate, oatmeal, coffee, burnt sugar, and some bitterness from the hops.  Medium-full bodied, with low carbonation and a slick, oily texture.  A bit too much smoke keeps the rest of the flavors from really popping, but this is really nice.  Roasty finish.  I tried this side-by-side with the Dark Horse Too Cream Stout, and this one wins in a pretty close call.

The smell on this bad boy was fantastic.  Nice chocolate and roast smell...loved it.  Had a pretty thin head, kind of to be expected.  Taste was ok,  honestly it felt just a tad thin, but as I let the glass warm a bit that improved.

Overall there are certainly better ones, but this was ok for the price.  This was a single 12oz bottle I paid around $1.99 for.
Black with a medium beige head. Aroma had dark chocolate, burned malt, hops and coffee hints. Flavour had burned malt, dark chocolate, coffee and oats. Finished full and roasted.
scura non molta schiuma non molto persitente naso non molto intenso sentori tostati caffe cioccolato cosi anche in bocca non molto corpo amaro non intenso un tocco etilico
Draft @ Capones. Black pour with brown head. Notes include coffee, chocolate, toffee, and roasted oatmeal. Decent brew.

bottle courtesy of coyotehunter, thanks! pours black with a dark brown head, nice foamy retention, lots of spotting.  aroma is slightly subdues, sweet, oaty, and a lil dough. nice medium body with lots of  toast and plenty of roast. another solid local from dark horse.

Bottle -- pours like dark blood, thick and rich in its dark colors.  The initially tan foam head dwindles quickly.  What little aroma there is here, its light and quiet -- with a hint of chocolate.  The drink delivers a bit more than that, with a rich chocolate character.  Good.  (#3789, 1/3/2010)
Thick dark motor oil pour with a nice dark brown head.  Slightly sour bitter roasted flavor.  Coffee finish with some fruit and berries.

One of several brews my wife ordered me for Christmas from beergeek.biz - 12oz bottle - black pour with a thin beige head that leaves a ring.  Pleasant milk chocolate and coffee aroma.  Medium roasted malt taste with the expected coffee and oatmeal.  Light to medium bodied with a metallic tint.  Was a little shocked to see this was 8% abv - dont detect any of the alcohol.  Overall a nice drinkable oatmeal stout.

12oz bottle, no date. Black with a thin ring of light brown foam, fades to a thin layer rather quickly with decent lacing. Aroma of dark chocolate with just a hint of yeast fruitiness. Big dark chocolate flavor, some nice roast malt, firm bitterness on the finish. Really impressed, was expecting a lack luster watery stout.

Wow, if ever there was a beer that gained from being let warm up. At first this seemed harsh and boozy, which of course doesnt make too much sense. Decent aroma, on the roasty chocolate side, as it warms the mouthfeel and flavor improve. Pretty decent. How does it compare to Kalamazoo or something like that? Well, Im not totally sure-Im not sure why this is in the sweet stout section.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown, small tan/brown head after a forced pour, dissipated quickly. Aroma is very faint touches of chocolate, lightly roasted malt and sweet vanilla notes. Roasted malt, coffee and subtle touches of chocolate are front and center, touches of vanilla and slight touch of hop hidden in the background at the finish. Body is very thin, would have liked this one to be a bit thicker, touch of bitterness on the finish.

Bottle from Bierkoning. Dark brown body with thinnest of heads. Nose of dark chocolate. Very nice. Full-flavoured chocolate, barley and coffee. Not too strong but well done. Dark chocolate in the finish. Nice and sweet. Enjoyable.
DecemBeer. Sample from a bottle shared by decaturstevo.  Dark brown, black, beige head.  Aroma is roasty, chocolate, oatmeal body.  Taste is very roasty, bitter chocolate.

Pours dark brown/black with a again a dark brown head.  Aroma: Roasted nut, cocoa butter, molasses.  Flavors are oatmeal and roasted malts with a well balanced hopped bitterness.  One of the many great Dark Horse stouts.

On tap at the Institute in Philly.  Pours an opaque, oily black with a lacing, creamy tan head.  Sweet aroma, brown sugar, nuts, coffee.  Strong chocolate flavor with coffee, nuts, toast, burnt grains, molasses and a little smoke.  Full bodied, sweet with a touch of bitterness on the end.  Very nice.  Even flavor while still being bold.
Tap at CAH.  Pours a deep brown with a medium creamy tan head.  Aroma and flavor of chocolate malt, roasted malt, coffee an nits.  Thin.

$8.99 / 4 Pack ---As expected, this is a fantastic oatmeal stout from Dark Horse.  This is my first beer from this brewery and Im impressed.  Nothing looks more wonderful than pitch black beer topped with dark mocha head.  Nice roasty malts with mocha and coffee.  Finally, a beer I can rate in the 4 region again--bit of a drought lately.

Now that is an Oatmeal stout!!! WOW.... pours tar brownish black with big chocolate colored head. nose is all sweet malts some chocolate and maybe a touch of coffee but not much. flavor is beautiful so smooth so creamy well freaking done!!!!!

Finally got to try one of these stouts.  A very nice well-rounded stout with a nice malty flavor and dry bitter finish.  The oatmeal adds to the aroma and texture.  Soft palate but not overly full bodied.  Easily drinkable and enjoyable.

Black viscous pour.  quickly dissipating tan head.  Aroma is cream and chocolate, some little gentle roast and some greaty oatiness.  from start to finish a sweet nuttiness.  Mouthful is thick and creamy, milk chocolate and some robust roast.  Really nice

Bottle. Pours near black with a mocha brown head. Roasty malty and coffee aroma with some sweeter malt notes. The flavor has smooth roasted coffee and oats with a light chocolate sweetness. Really good.

12 ounce bottle.  Served in a Sam Adams BL glass, the beer pours dark brown/black with about an inch brown head.  Head retention and lacing are both good.  Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, oatmeal and a bit of coffee and a smoky aroma.  However, the aroma is mostly sweet.  Taste is similar to the aroma, it tastes like bittersweet chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, charred/burnt malt and some oatmeal.  The taste is a lot more bitter than I expected it to be, at least compared to the aroma, anyway.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its rich, creamy and well carbonated.  Drinkability is good, its smooth and easy to drink.  Alcohol does hit you after drinking it, but you cant tell its 8% ABV in the taste at all.  Overall I think this is a good brew, I liked it and would buy it again.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours very dark brown with a medium sized dense tan head.  The aroma is heavy dark roasted malt, sweet rich caramelized malts, smooth dark chocolate, vanilla, and some char.  The flavor is very, very roasted with some hints of coffee and dark chocolate.  This beer is surprisingly smooth on the palate, probably due to the oatmeal, and has a medium-full body and a slightly creamy texture.  This beer only shows a mild sweetness, but isnt anywhere close to bitter.  I am usually pleased with the beers from Dark Horse and this is no exception.

Brewed in the USA.... Pours a very dark brown color with a super thin beige head. Aroma of oats, mats and some chocolate notes. Taste is much of the same with the addition of some coffee flavors. Mouthfeel is kind of thin yet very smooth with a sweet bitter finish. This stout is very drinkable and the 8% is hidden very well.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2011 Great oatmeal stout. nice appearance, taste. higher abv% is not noticeable...UPDATE 5-6-11..wow, this tastes a lot different to me these days. Very dark pour, beautiful dark brown head. SUPER ROASTY. also some noticeable alcohol burn. a bit of rubbing alcohol taste. thinner on the palate than i ever remember. bad bottle? im leaving my rating at 4 until further notice. this used to be my favorite oatmeal stout, this bottle did not live up to that.WHOA WHOA.. i let this stuff warm up a bit and the bitter alcohol burn is GONE. weird.

Draft at Capones. Poured a deep dark black body with an average sized frothy beige head. Aroma was perfect!!! Lots of coffee, oats, chocolate, roasty..simply awesome. The body was slightly thinner then I was expecting with soft carbonation and a bitter finish. The flavor had some definite earth and dirt notes, coffee grinds and bitter dark chocolate. As good as this beer was the aroma had me expecting a little bit more.

Bottle @ Kumas.  Pours black/dark brown with a nice tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, and some coffee.  Good thick flavor - coffee and chocolate stand out.  Slightly bitter, very enjoyable.  I might have to pick it up in the store.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2013 Cask Ale festival, Chelsea Pier, NYC.  Aroma is roasty, dark chocolate.  The apparance is true to the style, deep brown/black, tan head.  The flavor is coffee, chocolate, roasty, sweet.  The finish is roasted coffee bitter.  Not a standout, but enjoyable.

12 ounce bottle from my summer secret Santa. Pours a pitch black color with a thin brown head. Poor head retention and lacing. Aroma is lightly tart with notes of chocolate and light roast. Taste is rich, rich, roasted malts, chocolate, creamy notes from the oats, coffee, bitter hops, berries. Very smooth, creamy and a bitter finish. Medium bodied.
12 oz. bottle - dark brown with thin tan head; oats, roast and some chocolate; texture is thin as is the flavor profile; much like the TOO, this one was pretty bland and disappointing

Bottle. Pours thick and black with a little head. Leaves a yellow sheet of coating on the glass. Roasted grain, Hersheys chocolate bar and lacto aroma. Taste is smooth roasted grain, chocolate milk with a touch of bitterness. Finishes with a touch of chocolate. Just an awesome brew.
Bottle. Pours black, with a brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, oats, chocolate and coffee. Flavor is roasted malt, oats. coffee, dark chocolate, and a little alcohol. Body is a bit too thin.

Black pour with a brown head. Aroma of sweet malt, roasted malt, a little bit of coffee. Taste is nice and creamy, roasted malt, a little burnt taste. It left lacing on the glass. It leaves a nice roasted flavor in the mouth. All the tastes combine well. I bought a 4 pack and wish it came in a 6-er.

Bottle at home .. Thanks to Santa STFUN for this one ... nice solid shiney black with a nice tight breamy brown head ... soft sweet chocolate roast ... little coffee nose ... bit thin ... deep roast ... lots of coffee ... little bitter ... some chocolate ... quite a lot of hop .... not as sweet as id expect

Dark pour with no real head.  Moderate carbonation with a much lighter aroma than I expected.  Smells of roasted malts, chocolate, and hints of coffee.  Flavor was smooth and pretty much reflected the aroma.  It was a very drinkable stout.  I wouldnt say that it was anything to write home about but I would drink it again if I had the chance.

Draught at TJs:  Aroma of oats, chocolate, slight cream, and slight roasting.  Poured pitch black in color with a large, creamy, dense, brown head, that diminished but lasted throughout.  Slightly sparkling.  Flavor is lightly sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of chocolate, roasting, malts, slight tar, and oats.  Medium body.  Dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Chocolate, oat, and roasted malt finish is lightly dry.  Medium body.  Dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Chocolate, oat, and roasted malt finish is lightly dry.  8%ABV is totally hidden.
bottle thanks to daknole.  black with an espresso head. nose is oats, roasted malts and chocolate.  nice on the palate with a great roasted malt flavor and a chocolate finish.  very well done

On tap at B-dubs downtown Indy. Pours dirty black with nearly an inch of roasted brown head. Nose is sweet, chocolate and malt. This one is a very smooth drinker. Initial taste is a little more bitter than the aroma would lead on. Coffee, chocolate, barley/oats come to the forefront. Mouthfeel is a little slimy at times. Not too much depth, but very tasty and easy to drink.

Pitch dark pour and odd, hand-drawn label.  Sweet, malty aroma.  A full and flavorful stout that is nevertheless plenty smooth.  Coffee, strong fruity presence, prunes, and like puzzl said, a little marshmallow too.  A very fine stout, and another thank you to Adrian!

#348 for this beer, 12oz bottle. Very thick and black pour, another dense, deep abyss of a beer with a rather chocolatey tan head. Kind of a light milk chocolate aroma, light roast, not a huge aroma coming through. Roasty, slightly sweet and very smooth up front, has a nice bit of bitterness in the finish, more from the roasted malts than hops though, a bit of coffee in that finish. (969)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Pours black with thin tan head. Nose is alcohol, burnt grains, smoke. Flavor is roasted grain, dark chocolate, espresso, sweet caramel and tootsie roll. Full bodied. Awesome stout!

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2012 oily black with a small dark brown head.  heavy toasted burnt bread nose with dark chocolate.  oily full body.  lots of roast and marshmallow, cream.  big and robust.  motor oil. 

black with no head.  sweet chocolaty aroma with caramel and red fruit.  very low carbonation.  has a very oaty flavor with lots of caramel and chocolate.  sweet but not overly so.  medium-full bodied.  hints of vanilla and smores.  7/30/09

From coyotehunter via trade.  A super dark, almost viscous pour with a one-finger tall brown head.  A nice aroma of smoke, chocolate and plenty of caramel and brown sugar sweetness.  The flavor is roasty, smoky malts, light chocolate, brown sugar and some nice spicy hops towards the finish.  The mouthfeel is medium bodied and this was effortless to drink.  Good.
Bottle.  Black pour with a medium brown head.  Super malty aroma with chocolate cream.  Creamy chocolate flavor with some alchol presence and sweetness.

This poured a very dark brown color with a normal sized light tan head. Aroma was some sweet chocolate, lactose sugar, and roasted as well. Flavor was just what makes stouts great. Sweet chocolate, burnt malts, and roasted coffee, yum!

These guys just cant seem to make a bad stout. Poured almost still and almost black, I saw a little bit of head in others glasses though so I guess well say it can have a small head. Aroma is bacon like and smoky but still roasty. This one packs in some nice coffee flavors with a deep roasted malt and some burnt toast character, just slightly fruity with some raisin and dark fruit character. Very good.

Poured a very dark brown, almost black color with a nice tan head. Smelled of something smoked.. first impression was bacon, but later settled on popcorn. The flavor had a lot of chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, and oatmeal. Sweet finish

Thanks CanIHave4Beers! Not at all what I was expecting. Marshmallow, thanks for that descriptor Puzzl. Also, like freshly popped, unbuttered/altered popcorn, possibly tied in black patent. Aroma is a little smoky, like you burnt said popcorn. Flavor has nice black patent, but not nearly as much burnt toast as say, Decadence 07, but it is there. Some odd caramel biznus in there, part of the marshmallow, which is intriguing but maybe a bit much. Mouthfeel is a bit sticky. Low carbonation.

Bottled. Ive had this multiple times yet have no rating for it somehow, so here we go. Very creamy and chocolately, with some chalky and carbonic notes at the back. Sweet marshmallow in the finish with a touch of roasted coconut and espresso. Quite nice, especially as it warms.

Bottle at the RBSG09 grand tasting.  Black with a thick tan head.   Roasted grain, light coffee, chocolate, and copper penny aroma.   Dry and roasty with some dark chocolate.   Medium bodied.   Alright flavor, but weird aroma.

RBSG09 bottle at the grand tasting. Pours black with a huge fluffy brown head. Aroma is coppery; smells like a penny tastes. Underneath that there are notes of roasted malts and dark chocolate. Flavor is dark chocolate with a fat roasted character. A little astringent. Definitely the weakest of the DH seasonal stout series.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2009 12 ounce bottle that I decided to have on a summer day. I was pretty excited to have this stout. I am a huge fan of oatmeal stouts and really like Dark Horse. Pours an opaque black color with a half finger width tan head. This was the first stout by Dark Horse that I have seen with a head. The aroma consisted of sweet malt, bitter chocolate, and some coffee. The taste consists of oatmeal, sweet malt, and some bitter chocolate. As with most Dark Horse stouts, I thought this one was a bit light on the mouth feel but it did taste very good. Definitely my second favorite stout by Dark Horse... Plead the Fifth is definitely number one...

Bottle.  Pours an inky black with hardly any head.  Aroma of rich roasted malt, bitter chocolate, molasses, toffee, graham crackers, and booze.  Flavor is sweet initially with oatmeal, graham crackers and roasted malt in the finish.  Nice, robust palate.  Seems a bit strong to be classified as a stout rather than an imperial stout but oh well.  Very nice.
8/4/8/4/14 (3.8/5)

Bottle, thanks to tjthresh. Aroma of chocolate covered caramel, anise, black currant, cocoa powder. Flavor sweet with lots of dark fruits, really becomes the centerpiece in the mouth with the cocoa powder dancing around, as well as a coffee sort of bitterness, though not much coffee itself, just that sort of bitterness, if that makes sense. Very low carbonation, nearly syrupy, I think Id like a bit more to cut just a touch of the sweetness, but not so much that it really affects my rating... In any case, pretty complex sweet stout, and quite tasty.

Deep brown/black pour under a short head of dark mocha. Chocolate syrup and dark fruit aroma with mild licorice and a dark-roast graininess. Thick and syrupy to the palate.  Aroma translates almost directly to the flavor with bittersweet chocolate, fruits and red wine before a roasted coffee bitterness (mildly acrid) to finish. ~~~~~~~~~~~ Cellared nearly two years, purchased at Wacky Willys, Marshall, MI.

Ok. Dark brown with tan head with light aroma that grows as it warms. Kind of average roast coffee flavor with some bland grain (I guess thats the oatmeal), followed by some bright, and some bitter, fairly smooth, a bit sweet, but also strikes me as a bit thin. Overall pretty good but not one I need to pick up again.

Pours very dark brown to black with a 1 finger creamy tan head that has good retention. Aroma is mostly roast and a little espresso at first but as it warms some chocolate and oatmeal/cereal grains come out. Flavor is big on roast, oatmeal, dark chocolate, sweet barley, toasted oats, chicory like spice, dark caramel and some bitter hops. Palate is medium thickness with a chewy, substantial feel and a fairly lively carbonation that is never too sharp. Good stuff overall, deceptively smooth and easy going down for the 8%abv.
BOTTLE: thick, oily black pour, huge roasty nose. Nice roasty taste, rich full mouthfeel, maybe a touch sweet, but overall excellent.

12oz bottle.  Deep opaque black.  Mellow aroma.  Creamy and rich, full bodied.  Im quite surprised to see that it is 8%, as it is quite smooth and drinkable.  Roasty, with some coffee, chocolate, and a touch of syrupy brown sugar.  A touch of balancing bitterness that tastes more like chocolate than hops.  Quite a well done Stout.
pours a deep brown with a tan head.  sticky mouthfeel.  notes mocha, coffee, vanilla, roasted malts.  tasty.

Dark licorice and molasses aromas.  Very dark color with a brown head.  Head diminished quickly.  Coffee and dark roasted malty flavors.  Some sweet chocolate and expresso, light cream flavors, not much sourness.  Very smooth. Duration is fairly short on a medium rich palate.  Pretty good.

Bottle. A dark black color pour with a medium,lasting coco colored head. Aroma of chocolate,smoke,burnt malt,and coffee. Flavor is rich malty and sweet,chocolate,coffee,dark fruit,tobacco and a light bitterness that seems to be more from the chocolate and coffee than hops. Full body with a creamy mouthfeel,and a espresso type lingering finish. Very very good stout, Dark Horse makes some damn fine stout !

Bottle 355ml.Clear dark brown color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, chocolate, oat. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholic. [20081122]

Just another stroll in the park for dark horse Pour was black and thick like all of their beasty stouts with a dark thick tan head with aromas of roasted malts,coffee,chocolateflavors that leap out at you coffee,roasted chocolate malts that are roasted to perfection very full bodied and bold
12 oz bottle. Pours pitch black. smells of malts and roasted nuts. taste is simular.

2009 Bottle - Thanks BrewCzar! - Pours almost black with a small tan head...aroma is dk sweet molassas malt, dry fruit and chocolate...flavour is similar, dark, rich...finishes clean with a residual grainy malt...
bottle, very similar to the cream stout with more body, dark brown color with faint brown head, aroma of roast malt and fruity, flavors of cocoa, dark fruits, roasted nuts, longer finish

My least fave of the stout series (1,2,3)  I had high expectations since I loved the first two, and it was still very good just not up to par with the other 2 IMO.  Aroma of oatmeal, baking chocolate, and roasted nuts.  IN the flavor, all of the aforementioned and some toffee, weak coffee, and some carmel.
Tap.  Dark pour with a tan head.  Roasty and chocolaty.  Smooth and creamy with a silky and chalky finish.  Thanks sersdf.
Poured black with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Sweet chocolate and a hint of coffee. Kind of roasted at the finish.

12oz bottle courtesy of bitbucket.  Pours a nice black with brown tints and faint tan head that settles down to a small ring around the edge of my glass.  Roasty malt nose that has subtle coffee hints with some light sweetness.  Nice balance of sweet and roastiness with good body and not to much carbonation.  Very drinkable and the 8% is well hidden.

Bottle.  Pours a motor oil dark brown/black with a bubbly cola colored head.  Rich roasty oatmeal aroma, very sweet and malty with some more roast coffee notes.  Good lacing.  Flavor is dry roasty with slight char notes and a sweet chocolatey body.  Creamy feel.  Nice roast aftertaste.

In short: A splendid highly drinkable lightly roasted oatmeal stout.  Nothing original however this is incredibly drinkable.
How: Bottle 12oz.  Sent to me as a bonus by MatSciGuy.  Thanks a lot Levi, you really hit the spot with this one.
The look: Black body topped by a small tan head
In long:  Medium-low roastiness level, some roasted coffee beans, smooth velvety mouthfeel, that juicy black cereals thing that I only get from oatmeal stout, some berries (red and black), .  Interesting hops with a green pelett and tobacco leaves flavour.  This is everything a 5% session oatmeal stout should be except this one is 8%.  Dangerous.  Not that I mind being drunk, after all the only two ways I know to momentary forget about my problems is to get drunk or wear shoes two size too small.

This one actually finishes much better than it starts. Pours from the bottle to a jet balck-used motor oil color, with very little head from the outset and no lacing. Likewise, the nose is very faint and almost indistinguishable, but things get better from here. Mouthfeel is full and sweet, and the taste is a pleasant blend of chocolate, vanilla and toffee. 8% alcohol is very subtly pleasant in the taste as well, and this all blends to a finish that is long and just sweet enough.

12 oz bottle. Interested in the Dark Horse stouts, so I figures I would try this even though I dont like oatmeal stouts. Pours a dark black with a tiny brown head that disappates quickly. Smells of Chocolate, roasted coffee, and malt. Tastes of chocolate, lots of oats, and a metallic tint. Kind of weak-bodied, not leaving any residual taste. Overall its pretty smooth, but nothing special.

12 oz. bottle. Stout, almost syrupy pour, very few scraps of brown foam. Big smell of roast barley and Kahlua, even for an 8% beer. Closer up, the Kahlua smell is even sweeter, almost cloying. Taste tells a slightly different story. A bit of cola texture; somewhat oily, then some coffee type bitterness. Does hold together nicely, missing only a more velvety smoothness from the usual oatmeal stouts. But that may not have been easy to do at this strength. But its very agreeable. Im not feeling the alcohol just yet, that probably waits until Ive finished it. I do like these one-off series from my favorite microbrewers; theyre lots of fun.

Very thick and almost black pour.  A small tan head.  Aroma is dark fruit with chocolate and some must.  Tastes of anise, chocolate, and cherries.  It warms as chocolate covered cherries and it is sweet enough that even the syrup seems to be there.  A nice zesty feel with a smooth, thickness.  Nice!

Bottle.  Pours a moderate black, deep brown, with little brown head.  Aroma is faint, but of molasses, sweet roasted grains, and a little chocolate.  Taste is nice, a fuller body of sweetened oats and chocolate.  Taste is secondary to the body and palate.  A big, chewy body, nice overall drink.

Bottle. Pours a thick black molasses with a small burnt tan head. Nose is rich with chocolate, molasses, prune, and black licorice. Flavors are similar with hints of coffee and a slight hop spice. Mouth is medium to full bodied with a slight alcohol burn and a mild bitter finish. Enjoyable sweet stout!

12 oz bottle pulled from the Binnys Singles Rack (Orland Park, IL) sometime ago and that sat in my fridge for a while. Pours a nice thick black with brown notes on the edges and moderate brown head that laces enough. Aromas hit me out of the bottle: light grainy oatmeal cookie sweetness, light roasted malt, some creamy vanilla and cocoa. Very nice. Initial is lighter bodied than expected, but not necessarily light, a nice light roasted taste overtaken by sweeter oatmeal, vanilla, light cocoa, and very subtle coffee notes with smooth body that slips down the throat easily. Roast comes through a little fuller further into the body. Tame, but enjoyable. Hard to place a finger on the 8% ABV tag.

12 oz. bottle, courtesy of Beerlando.  Dark black pour with a thin, tan head.  Aroma of oats, dark chocolate, and a hint of coffee.  Silky mouthfeel.  Flavor is really nice.  Lots of roasted malt and chocolate.  Finish is smoky and bitter.  Nice beer.

12-oz. Thanks, SuzyGreenberg! Or BVC. lol
Jet black, light ruby highlights. Headless and laceless. Big sweet chocolate nose. Creamy medium body. CHocolate, salty, and smoky mid-palate. Clean, campfire-y, bacony finish. Not sure if they meant it to be smoky, judging by the commercial description, but it was definitely grubbin.
Bottle. Pours black with small brwnish head.  Aroma: coffee, roasted malt, and cocoa.  Flavor: Roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, medium bitter.
Black pour similar to motor oil. Tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, caramel, chocolate. Flavor or strong roasted malts and coffee. Dark chocolate in the after taste. Medium body.

I love it when I start drinking a new beer that at first Im not sure of, but by the time Im done, Im in love. This is definitely one of those beers. Its full of roasted malt and subtle chocolate and even less coffee, but it all comes together very nicely. It poured a very dark brown opaque with a 1 inch brown sugar head.   Very nice, Cheers!

Bottle from Archer Liquors. Dark black color with a large dark tan head. Aromas of chocolate and coffee. Light medium body with creamy carbonation. Flavor of coffee and chocolate. Finishes fairly smooth and lightly bitter. Good stout. Satisfying.

Bottle.  Pours black as night.  Thin dark tan head.  Very little lacing.  Aroma of chocolate and roasted coffee beans.  Very much of a coffee flavor.  Starts of sweet and creamy but has a more bitter finish  (if that makes any sense).  Good mouthfeel.  I didnt really get the oatmeal taste that I was expecting, but frankly oatmeal is pretty bland.  This beer was very satisfying.  The slight bitterness and full bodied nature set is aside from some of the lesser stouts.  Excellent beer for the long Michigan winters.  Another quality beer produced by the guys at the Darkhorse.

12 oz. bottle. Jet black with light tan, fizzy head. Smells like bourbon, chocolate, and toffee. Starts sweet and malty, then turns bitter. Bourbon and slight metallic finish. A nice stout, but a little bitter for my taste.

pitch black pour with almost no head and slight lacing around the edges. Roasted malts along with a touch of sweetness. Flavor is much of the same with a trace of the oats at the very tail end. And it finishs extremely well. I think it is very drinkable and very enjoyable.

Pitch black color.  Very small almost dark tan head that quickly dissipates.  Strong roasted malt flavor.  Very well balanced with malts on the front end and mildly bitter finish.  This is an excellent sweet stout.

[Bottle] Pours a clear dark brown with a smallish tan head. Aroma has some slight oat notes, a little sweetness, and a lot of roastiness. Flavor is very rich and smooth, with roasted malts on the front with a lack of oatmeal character. Dry and roasty finish. I would have liked a little more oat expression in the flavor and finish.

Thanks to northernbrews for the bottle!Near-black brown, thin tan head that will disappear before your eyes. Lots of chocolate, oat, and coffee in the nose with a very minor fruit and licorice that is barely detectable. Flavor is very sweet and milky with more of the above but less roast. Body too thin but complimentary of the sweeter nature. Finish is pretty long and big on roast. Very drinkable, though a little simple.

This is called a sweet stout, but I didnt get a large amount of sweetness.  Flavor was ultra roasted with just a hint of sweetness.  Just enough to balance everything out.  Very good flavor.  Aroma is coffee and chocolate, and fairly strong.  Good mouthfee, medium to thick.

Aroma is pure chocolatey roastiness. You can smell this stuff when you pop the cap. Pours medium black with tan head. Flavor is slightly sour from the milky aspects of the oatmeal, but carries a smoky, roasty and dark flavor throughout.
Crushed with Jakebra thanks to Honkeybra.  Sweet nose.  Chocolatey smoothness and some bitter burntness.  Definitely excellent and above average.
dark black with nice tan head.  thick mouthfeel, low carbonation.  nice sweetness with a nice roasted component with some sweet oats.  alcohol provides depth.  very nice

12 oz. bottle.  Looked like oil pouring into the glass.  Small tan head that quickly disappeared. Aroma of chocolate and roasted coffee. Initial taste of sweet, malt and chocolate. Finishes with a slightly bitter taste of roasted coffee. 
Pretty creamy mouthfeel.  Not a bad stout.

Pours black with a nice, tan head. Coffee, chocolate, and roasty nose. Flavor is slightly burnt with lots of coffee and chocolate. Maybe a bit of a fancy coffee drink, but lots of cream and coffee. Basically awesome for an oatmeal stout.

Thanks 17thfloor! Pours jet black with a thick creamy tan head Aroma is heavy molasses and chocolate and roasted malts. Very pronounced coffee and a slight dark fruitiness that gives a nice crispness in the nose. Flavor starts out with a quick hit of chocolate and oats. Very strong vanilla and coffee creamer-like sweetness in the middle. Finishes with a nice hit of dark chocolate bitterness and a lingering creamy mouth feel. Medium body and moderate to high carbonation. Really nicely rounded stout with a solid complexity and tasty creaminess.
I cannot get enough of this style. All chocolate and coffee and everything that makes this the perfect beer int he middle of the winter.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a deep, thick black with a tan head that has nice retention and decent lacing.  Aroma is lots of chocolate malt.  Lots.  There is that slight burnt character in there as well as a bit of coffee.  Smells nice.  Flavor is a nice burnt coffee and chocolate.  Nothing too harsh, just right.  The oatmeal in this bad boys makes it an easy drinker too.  Good beer.  Good beer.

Pour is a deep chocolate brown with a half inch dark tan head. Scents of roasted malts hops oats and notes of coffee. heavy oatmeal on the palate, with bits of roasted malt and a creaminess nestled with a hint of sour. Not sticky in the least to me, but still, ok.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2009 Syrupy black with a thinnish but sticky dark brown head. Sweet black coffee, chocolate, and fruit in the nose. Flavor is sweetish and bitter with a bit of fruity sourness, but quickly morphs into a smoky coffee and chocolate finish that linger for a long time. Medium  body. Quite good.
Bottle. Fruity and roasted aroma. Totally black colour, small light brown head. Good roasted flavour, creamy. Hint of sourness, very nice coffee roastedness. Creamy aftertaste.

12oz bottle. Pours black with small tan head. Aroma is chocolate, roasted malt, light coffee and vanilla. Flavor is roasted malt and chocolate, with coffee and vanilla. Medium body and finishes dry and some coffee bitterness. A little to dry for my palate but still a decent stout.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of fiver29. Completely opaque black with a light brown head. Sweet vanilla and roasted malt in the nose. Medium body, hard roasted malt, a little coffee and chocolate and a dry, lightly bitter finish. 221108
Bottle, at WeeHeavySDs Halloween tasting, with thanks to me!  What?  I guess I forgot I brought it.  Who gave me that?  No head.  Black color.  Dryish.  Some roasted grains.  Pretty nice.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2010 Pours a thinner very dark chestnut brown with a very small thin mocha head.  I love the creamy semi-sweet vanilla oatmeal chocolate aroma, rich coco powder and light molasses.  First taste is a bit darker and more bitter than the aroma leads on.   Deep roast, coffee, with a touch of chocolate and some mellowing oatmeal.  The Oatmeal flavor is good, however the coffee takes the lead is the longest lasting in the the finish.   Medium body, close to thin, lightly chalky with lots of active fluffy medium bubbled carbonation.

12 oz bottle.  Pours opaque black with a tan head.  Strong, sweet chocolate aroma with roasted coffee and toffee.  Flavor is almost exactly like eating dark chocolate, with some roasty coffee in there and a hint of vanilla.  Quite nice.

12oz bottle. Pours black with a small brown head that quickly dissipates. Aroma is of oatmeal, malt, coffee, Cheerios, and chocolate. Taste was of burnt coffee, oatmeal, malt, and some mild chocolate. Lingering coffee taste after each sip. Mouthfeel is creamy and sticks to the gums. Drinkable, but missing something. Too underwhelming for my tastes.

almost black in color, with no head. aromas of chocolate, vanilla, and burnt coffee/espresso. very chocolate and a touch of alcohol hottness. good stout, but thought the oatmeal would give it a rounder mouthfeel.

Bottle, at WeeHeavySD’s Halloween tasting, with thanks to wetherel! Pours a deep black with a tan ring. Aroma is rich and smoky, of grilled meat, malt, oats, chocolate, and a hint of sweeter dark fruits. Taste has a lot of smoke, with malt, meat, oats, and chocolate. Lingering smoky meat flavors. Big and tasty.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2010 Draft at Jerrys. Black with big, foamy, chocolate shake head / Winey nose of bittersweet chocolate and oatmeal / Medium to full body, creamy, with good balance and long, chewy, dry, finish / Toasty flavors of tobacco, bittersweet chocolate, oatmeal, vanilla, and dark roast coffee / Not super complex as the best of them, but very good.

Beer Tasting at Heritage Liquor(Maplewood, MN) -  Pours a very deep dark brown in color. The nose is slight coffee, some deep black malt and a fair amount of dark chocolate. This smells very promising. You get a bit more of the roasted coffee in the flavor, but its not dominant or obtrusive. Theres just enough dark chocolate to balance it out.  Comes across the palate fairly smooth. There is a bit of bitterness from the roasted barley.

Draft at Hop Leaf. Pretty pedestrian, pours a dark brown. Kinda roasty, though rather subdued. Sweet and some coffee and chocolate comes out, though it has that bad astringent acridness to finish it. Meh.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2008 On tap at the Bavarian Lodge, Lisle, Il. Starts with a rich, black/brown hue with a clingy, reducing, dark tan head. Smoke, toffee, roasted coffee, cocoa, etc..Creamy mouth feel due to the oatmeal with a prevailing medium bitter/dryness. Very pleasant, full bodied stout.
On tap at brewery.  Pours black with little head.  Taste is mocha and smooth on the mouth.  Some lacing.  A bit thin mouthfeel fro my taste.

12 oz bottle:  Aroma has big hints of roasted malts, chocolate, almost a flowery scent, candy like, and some really dark roasted coffee.  Appearance is all the way black with a thick tan head that lingers.  Taste is really roasty, coffee on the backend, oatmeal is really prevalent in the taste.  Almost a wet oatmeal taste to it.  Chocolate and the roasted malt.  Overall, damn good fresh. Creamy, Roasty, and all around a hell of a good stout. IMHO.  Cheers!
bottle. has a roasted malt aroma with a hint of chocolate. pours a thick black with no head. taste is cold coffee with a bit of a bitter malt. dark chocolate finish.
Wow, serious and dark beer. Nice carbonation, long lasting cocoa with coffee notes. Really dark, no head. Roasted malt, chocolate aroma. Watery consistency, thin beer.

Pours a very dark brown almost black in color.  There is a very short lived frothy head on the pour.  But alas, it is gone before I get to my chair.  Smell is slight coffee, some deep black malt and a good amount of dark chocolate. This smells very promising.  You get a bit more of the roasted coffee in the flavor, but it’s not dominant or obtrusive.  There’s just enough dark chocolate to balance it out.  Mouthfeel is pretty decent and fairly smooth.  There is a bit of bitterness from the roasted barley, coffee.  A very solid, good offering from Dark Horse.

12 oz bottle. Poured deep black with a medium sized dark brown head that left little lacing on the glass. Aroma of oatmeal, coffee, and roasted malts. Taste of toasted malts, burnt or charred malts, light oatmeal, with a bitter chocolate finish. Not bad.
Aroma is like a toasted pumpernickel loaf with some cocoa in the background.  Flavor is lightly sweet.  Not super complex, but pretty well balanced and tasty.

Bottle Shared with GMCC2181., Thanks Gabe. Poured a very dark black color with a reddish head and nice lacing. Aroma  is oats, smoke, and malts. Taste is similar with coffee. very thick but enjoyable.

Bottle from stfun...thanks josh! Black as black can get. Toffee colored head, good lacing. Taste is burnt roasted malts and a touch of coffee. Texture was oily but thick, still drinkable though. Close to southern tiers oatmeal stout. Good stout. Thanks josh!

12 oz. bottle thanks to a trade with yem25.  Pours a thick, dense black with a moderate dark brown head that faded to a film after about a third of the glass and left a very thin, nearly clear, sheet of foam with each sip that quickly slid back down into the beer.  If this thing had any kind of decent head retention, this would have easily been a "5" for appearance.  Pleasant aroma of roasted malt and chocolate.  The flavor is roasted malt with some coffee and bittersweet chocolate.  Very mild sweetness overall.  A bit dry as it approaches the finish.  Full bodied.  Enjoyable.

Bottle courtesy on StFun.  Looks like crude oil coming out of the bottle and settles a dense black with a fast receding one finger tan head in my glass.  Very spotty lacing.  Nose is dark fruits, smoked oats, something sour that I can’t place, and dark chocolate.  Taste is very roasty with black coffee, baker’s chocolate, toasted oats and molasses.  Charred and bitter finish.  Full creamy mouth feel.  Great beer and brewer.  Thanks Josh!

12oz bottle.  Pours dark as night with a thin brown head which produced irregular lacing.  Nose is of espresso and roast malt.  Taste is definitely coffee with a little chocolate.  Mouthfeel is medium but not full, and is very smooth for a stout.  No harshness in the texture.  Easy drinking and tasty.

Pours oil slick black out of the bottle with a small dense mocha head that lingered for a while as a cap and then left a ring with a little lacing.  Aroma is burnt malts with espresso and licorice.  There is also a bit of sweetness in the smell as it warms with milk chocolate and vanilla.  The taste is also big of the roasted/burnt malt character.  The first taste is a sweet chocolate and vanilla blast which gives way to coffee and roasted malts.  The sweetness of the malts lingers through the finish with a slight coffee bitterness.  The mouthfeel is full bodied with a little carbonation which just coats the mouth with the massive malt flavors.  This is a good, if fairly one-dimensional (roasted malts) stout and I look forward to the rest of the stout series.
Pours black with thin tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt and chocolate.  Taste is also roasted malts, raisins, molasses, and chocolate.  Thick, chewy mouthfeel.  Solid beer.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 Bottle, hurricane glass, drunk at cellar temp.  Big roasty aroma.  Dark brown pour becomes black in the glass, almost no head, leaves the glass clean.  First sip is a roast monster, chocolate malts come out in force, hints of dark fruits.  Finishes fruity-bitter, like unripe peaches or green melon.  After the first couple sips, the mouth is quickly acclimated to the roasted barley, and except for the fruit notes at the end, it becomes a beer more felt than tasted.  Thick creamy mouthfeel here, slightly phenolic.  With the roast elements out of the way, several subtler flavors can be picked out: vanilla, anise, burnt toast are all here, but for the most part the front becomes somewhat cola-like, though not really sweet, and infinitely creamier.  A little grapey in the final afterglow.

12 oz. bottle served in pint glass- poured non transparent black when held to a light source, low carbonation, brownish tan ring around the glass for a head that had some lacing, aroma of a hearty dark roasted malt with notes of molasses and cofee.  Hits the mouth with a wide body, malt is very noticeable, coffee taste is hearty and lasts well past the finish, very little sweetness noticed.  Kind of hard not to like it...

Thanks to puzzl for this generous gift.  I was warned that this might be past prime, but it’s pretty damn delicious.  Pitch black topped by a thin espresso crema head.  Aroma is quite lovely.  Rich cocoa and espresso with a luxurious dark chocolate nose.  Fairly roasty with lots of dark rich sweet maltiness.  A bit of tobaccoish/leathery character as well.  The flavour is great.  Soft rich milk chocolate, molasses and a lingering soft sweetness.  Smooth oaty/creamy palate.  Excellent rich body, softly herbal through the middle with a touch of sweet plummy fruit as well.  Soft lightly roasty chocolate finish.  Really tasty.

Bottle from mmm////beer. Black pour with no real head.  Aromas of molasses, syrup, malt.  Flavor is boozy, malty and raisins.  palate is a bit watery.  A bit disapponted to be honest.  Good but not what I thought it might be.

12 oz bottle. Nice oateal stout! Poured a dark brown with a minimal tan head. Aroma was of dark malt with a touch of sweet. The flavor was malty, with a little chocolate and coffee thrown in. Not bad at all.

12oz bottle via trade with mmm///beer.  Pours black with no head.  Main aromas were coffee, toasted malts and some chocolate.  This stout didn’t do a whole lot for me.  Don’t get me wrong, it was good, just didn’t live up to my expectations.
Poured pitch black from the bottle with a trim dark brown head that quickly dissappated.  Plenty of molasses, oatmeal and alcohol in its aroma.  Malty with a dry coffee finish.
A deep dark black pour with deep tan head and lace. Aroma of toasted malt and coffee. Flavor of chocolate and coffee. A medium bodied beer that is just excellent. Very solid

Dark brown with a thin brown head.  Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, sweet malts, mild alcohol and light peat.  Taste of roasted malt, coffee, alcohol, oatmeal, chocolate.  Thick bodied, not overly alcoholic and finishes with some mild malt bitterness.  Decent stout.

had with stumac and melanie ... second session ... quite smokey and a bit meaty, bold for a oatmeal/sweet stout ... dark as a struck match in a box wearing a diving suit under water ... slick and oily, chewy stuff here ... sweet vanilla notes ... what did stu spill again??

Courtesy of CigarCityBrew. Pours dark darkness with dark brown edges and thin tan head. The aroma is roasty, mildly burnt, oatmeal like, black licorice, some vanilla and some chocolate. The taste is rich, smooth and yummy. I get roasty to burntness. More yum. I also get chocolate smoothness, coffee and sweet caramel. Wow, everything comes together nicely. Very very tasty brew.

The Dan Journal #198.  Tasted 7/10/08.  12oz bottle.  Dark brown hue with a khaki head.  Aromas of raisins, toffee, coffee and a woody character.  Full bodied with a bitter, rich and sticky palate.  Vanilla creamy flavors.  Really good!

Bottle. Pours pitch black with an extremely dark dan head. The aroma has lots of a dark fruit tang mixed in with roasty, smokiness. Oatmeal as well as bitter cocoa and hints of coffee is also noticeable in the aroma. I was a little bit surprised at how light the brew felt to the tongue. It also has a little bit of oiliness to it that is best attributed to coffee oils. The initial flavour is mildly sweet of darker fruits combined with some chocolate. Shortly after, though, a light bitterness grabs the tongue as the cocoa and roastiness begin to burst. The tangy dark fruits continue to be quite noticeable. It isnt until the dark fruit flavours start to diminish when the oatmeal begins to surface. Towards the finish, the dark fruit merely becomes a shadow as oatmeal becomes dominant. Cocoa, light coffee, and roasty flavours merely complement the oatmeal. There is a slightly noticeable bitterness in the finish as well. This is very tasty and theres a lot going on in the flavour.

Nice opaque pour, roasted aroma from a nice tan head.  Good roasted malt, just a hint of dark chocolate.  Dark Horse likes to hop their brews, this has a hint of that, not too much though.  Very good representation of the style.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle from Styles. A decent appearance, although it didnt jump out as outstanding by looking at it. After that, though, a darned nice brew. Excellent robust body and mouthfeel opens up and fortifies an outstanding and rounded flavor of light coffee and cocoa chocolate, very nice roasty touch and oatmeal finish. A solid oatmeal stout. Thanks so much, Chris.

Bottle cold. Very dark to black with a dense, short-lived head. Nice aroma of fresh apples and new mown grass. Sharp malt with creamy mouth. The oatmeal quality is apparent in every sip and a sour flavor with small hop bitter gets the job done for this rather unique ale. Ill drink all four!

Bottle courtesy of someone from the Tampa crew. Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma of coffee, roasted malt, and oats. Taste is the same as aroma with hints of bitter chocolate. Medium thin mouthfeel with a mild amount of bitterness and very well hidden alcohol. Very good.

Bottle, courtesy CigarCityBrew, I think. Pours black with brown highlights. Creamy head with nice lacing. Roasted malts in the nose, chocolate and oats, vanilla, and coffee beans. Tons of roasted malts in the mouth, chocolate, coffee, oats, cereal. Finish is big and has tons of roasted notes. Body is somewhat light, extremely drinkable.

Near black with a light brown head. Big milky sweet blackened malt aroma with vanilla. Ultra smooth and full bodied. Smooth, rich roasted malt flavors with some smoky pipe tobacco earthy sweetness lingering to the finish. These guys know how to make good stouts.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle at Noogfest Four-O.  Pours black with amber edges, orange-beige head. The aroma is roasty coffee with some chocolate and the berry tones I usually associate with oats. Flavor is roasty with bitter chocolate and notable hop taste in the finish. Not bad.

Pours a dark brown colour with very little head. No lacing, and flavors of a dark roast coffee, and espresso beans. Aromas of dark chocolate and oak, a tad bit heavier and drier than most oat stouts, but very nice.
There is a rich chocolatey aroma with actual oatmeal aroma and a slightly harsh edge. Slick body. Lingering bitterness. Satisfying.

Bottle courtesy of ogglethorp.  Poured a thick black with ruby highlights and a large frothy brown head.  Pleasant aroma of dark fruits, a bit of chocolate and cream and a touch of bitter hops.  Flavor is quite smooth with notes of cream, cocoa, a bit of coffee beans leading to a mild bitter coffee finish.  Flavor is sufficiently roasty without being oppressively bitter.  Easy drinking and very nice.
Bottle  Pours a black body with a tan head.  Aroma is sweet malt, chocolate, and some coffee and oats.  Flavor is just that malty, coffee and a little etoh.

Bottle at Noogfest 08. Pours black with a wisp of a brown head. Full bodied with a slick oily mouthfeel. Aroma of iced coffee and dark roasted malts. Flavor of dark chocolate, smoke, and coffee with a nice balancing bitterness.  Not overly sweet, but just enough to make this a solid and balanced drinker. Alcohol well hidden on the finish.

Bottle acquired via trade with polomagnifico...THANKS RYAN!!!  Intense aroma of bitter chocolate, grain, and slow roasted kona beans.  Appearance was a shade of midnight with mahogany glowing around the edges.  A very small and short-lived cocoa-colored head.  Flavor has all of the traditionally represented flavors but no "shock & awe".  Very glad I had a chance to try this!!!

Pours viscous, opaque black, with a quarter-inch head that fizzles out quickly. A few dots of lacework and barely a whisp of brown foam remain after.

Aromatics are chocolaty, fudgy, and roasty.
Brownie batter laced with chocolate syrup and a shot of espresso.

Full bodied and chewy. Oily and silky.

Loads of chewy, creamy stout character on the pallet. Dark chocolate, roasted malts, fudge nuggets, and rich espresso. The oatmeal really adds depth and smoothness. Very rounded and velvety.
A terrific amount of balance for such a big brew. Bitterness and hopping in other regards is subdued, allowing what a great Oatmeal stout is to shine through.

Finishes with a tongue-wrapping amount of choco-roast, and hints of residuals and drying char.

Bottle, courtesy of BossHossBikes. This is surprisingly black with a symmetric brown head and nice rolling cascades after I swirl the snifter. The aroma is heavily roasty with notes of ash, fig, chocolate, raisins, coffee, a slight sour tinge, and soy sauce. hm. This is a delightfully smoky stout with hints of tobacco and dark roasted coffee. The sweetness present is minimal and makes the brew seem creamy, perhaps a tad chocolaty.  Hops come out just a bit and add tasteful bitterness to the sweet, roasted, earthy body. This is definitely a winner in my book.

Bottle.

Pours s deep black, viscous with a limited dark-tan head, leaving an iodine-colored lacing along the the sides of the glass when I swirl (have to admit I find that yellow tone somewhat offputting). Dark-roast aroma, hints of cherry juice. Roasty, almost smoky flavor, plenty of hops driving the whole affair to a relatively bitter finish. Tar, coffee, a whisp of soy sauce, mild sweetness.

Altogether quite a nice beer.

Bottle. Another solid stout from Dark Horse. Black body with a foamy, tan head that disappears. Aromas of vanilla, coffee, chocolate, roasted malt. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. The finish is bitter.Flavors of licorice, espresso. Medium body, creamy smooth texture. Moderate carbonation. Very nice.

Pours a thick tar like color with very dark tan head that very quickly dissipates to no head....barely even lacing. Aroma is of definite espresso grounds. amazingly strong aroma. Flavor is of malts and espresso. Bitter chocolate flavors. Definite nut undertones.  Carbonation is light. A very delicious oatmeal stout....delicious
This poured black in color with a very thin head of brown bubbles.  The oatmeal was prominent in the nose and mouth along with a smokey/metallic edge.  This was meidum-bodied, smooth and engaging.

more thanks to fantomas!  Rich dark fruit, a little tar, with some alcohol in the nose.  Pours black with no head.  It looks thick!  Strong dark fruits, intense, some tobacco, bitter chocolate and burnt coffee in the finish.  good beer.
dark brown body with a light brown head.mostly smoke and roast in the flavor and aroma.good stuff overall.
