Bottle into stem glass.  Purchased at Discount Liquor, Milwaukee.  Opaque black in the glass.  A winey film covers the side instead of lacing.  Smell: some oatmeal mustiness and a slight acidity reminiscent of bourbon, plus unmasked alcohol.  Acidic in the mouth.  Chocolate flavor is thin in the middle, but lingers a long time.  The middle is mostly grainy and musty.  Finish is acidic and chemically dry, with nice oats and a hard sweetness late.  Moderately roasty.

Bottle. Heavy nose of roasted malt, oatmeal, toasted marshmallow. Some alcohol and a whiff of smoke. Pours like motor oil. Jet black with a rich, reddish amber head. Flavor was lots of dry roasted malt. Some nice hop bitterness on the back end. A hint of vanilla and coffee. Fairly full bodied and creamy on the palate.

Thanks to someone (Immy perhaps?) for sending me this bottle. Its a nice stout for sure. It had a few things that could either be better or more pronounced, but the sum of the beer was clearly above average. The beer pours out of the bottle in a thick streak of ooey black goodness. It hits the glass and immediate creates a light chocolately brown head with tiny bubbles being the base for some big foamy bubbles. The head disappates rather quickly unfortunately and whats left is a black coffee looking brew with no semblance of a head. My sniffer picks up anise immediately. Sweet, roasted, wet malts are next. Some obvious coffee notes too. But underlying all of it is this odd irony, metallic character that is really unpleasant. It kinda reminds me of drinking a stout from a can character. Mouthfeel is smooth with a hotness brought on by the alcohol content, but as it warms up that disappears a bit. Flavor isnt horrible. Perhaps a step-up from average. Strong with coffee with a shot of alcohol clearly present. Some vinous notes started creeping in as it really got to room temp. Subtle chocolate notes that I wish were more prevelent were also popping up. Id like to have my sweet stouts a bit sweeter than this as this was a bit dry I thought. Overall not bad. Not sure if I could (or would) drink more than a pint of this. It could have been more smooth, less alcoholic, a bit sweeter with more complexity. Overall, a nice beer.

TRUMP! Wow, this brew pours black as 30wt with 100k miles on it. The creamy spattered froth only rises a fingers width, but has a beautiful bronze color. Head retention is a little short lived and rduces to a partial yet fluffy lace. Aromas of creamy roasted leathery malts makes my mouth water. Full nectar w/ soft and velvety residual effers creates a rather sensuous brew. The brew glides in silky then turns to velvet on the way down. The mildly sweet flavor profile starts out w/ heavily roasted viscous malts. Then the defined asprin bittering component kicks in to balance. Roasted coffee bean, bitter cocoa, leather, and bit-o-black cherry. The finish is long and savory leaving behind a tastey roasted cocoa residue and a perfect bittering component. Highly recommended.

Bottle courtesy of puzzl (thanks Andy!).  Poured black with no head at all, just a tan ring.  Slight aroma of roasted malts and chocolate.  Taste is mostly chocolate, with some roasty coffee flavor in the background.  Its got that oatmeal smoothness I enjoy so much on the palate.  Finish is more on the roasted coffee end.  An enjoyable brew.  Cant wait to try the rest.

12oz. pours black with tan creamy head. nose is oats, milk chocolate, wet grains, and coffee. flavor is rich milk chocolate, roasty, dark coffee, and oats. mouth feel is creamy this is a nice stout. I like most of the stouts in the series but really hate the artwork.

Bottle:  Pours black with a brown head, little lacing.  Nose is mild of roast with coffee and cocoa.  Flavor is true to the oatmeal stout with nice accents of coffee and chocolate, light roast.  Solid.  Thanks EithCubes.

Pours black with a brown, mild head. Light aroma of coffee and chocolate. Thick mouth feel with a strong bitter, back mouth flavor. Very heavy qualities of coffee and chocolate. Strong alcoholic warmth at the end. Not a bad beer, but it is a little two-dimensional

12 oz bottle: poured black with a small brown head. Aroma is of coffee, some roasted malts and chocolate. Flavor is more coffee, roastiness, but less chocolate than I would have thought. Has an alcohol bite to it. Is also quite dry. Bitter finish.

Dark brown color with a thin and fine tan head. The aroma is immeadiatly apparent and very nice. Lots of roasted malt notes with some chocolate. The flavor isnt that special until it gets to the point where it is almost too warm. There is a ton of chocolate in the flavor and some light roasted malts in the finish rounding out a nice delicious brew with a dry roast aftertatse. This one is very well done.

12 oz bottle
I have been sitting on this bottle for a while and decided it was finally time to crank it open.  In an attempt to thin the herd I am working through the beers which either will not age gracefully or will not improve in the cellar.  This one was probably five months old when I opened it at the end of June.  The local store has more left though Im not sure I will pick it up - this did not strike me as a particularly good beer to sit on for more than a few months.
Aroma / Appearance - The black body is opaque without being too dark as a moderate amount of light can still sneak through.  A half finger tan colored head sits on top like mocha frosting.  Cinnamon, oatmeal, bittersweet chocolate and vanilla form the principal scents which are complimented by smoke and coffee.  This has all the hallmarks of a sweet stout based on the nose.
Flavor / Palate - Peat blended with dark chocolate, smoke and coffee beans which have been roasted almost to the point of being burned form the first impression.  Next comes cocoa, more smoke and carbonation.  A lingering bitterness sits underneath everything to provide a point of reference.  While it is not chewy the mouthfeel is still thick enough to be satisfying.  The richness is offset by a subtle sweetness.  Im glad to have tried this one and wish I would have had the foresight to pick up the Fore as well.

Had a bottle or two of this a while back courtesy of Duane.  My dad always hooks me up with the good stuff.  Very black pour, roasty malt and sweet residual sugar aroma.  Velvety mouthfeel with lots of roated malt, dark chocolate, and a nice amount hop flavor floating around in there.  Very sweet and the alcohol is extremely well hidden.  Thanks dad!

12oz bottle from EithCubes - thanks! Man, this is exactly the kind of beer that spins my rotor, even in the dank early summer humidity. A big roasty stout, with a rich chocolate body and some bready oatmeal heft. Very dry finish but not quite as thick as Id want. Overall very fine, though, and I hope to have this again.

Pours deep dark brown, almost black with a small head.  Smells roasty.  Taste is super roasty with some chocolate hints and distant hops.  Quite creamy.  Taste gets a little one dimensional after awhile, but nice and thick and full flavored for an oatmeal stout.  Good beer.
Roasted malt aroma with light coffee.  Black body with a medium head.  Full palate.  Lots of really strong coffee flavors with some chalky tastes and a hint of chocolate.  Nice.

12 ounce bottle from BBB63
Pours black with a cappaccino brown colored head.  The aroma has the aroma of those no bake drop cookies that my mom used to make me.  Lots of oats and cocoa.  The flavor has that kind of twang that I associate with oatmeal stouts.  Nice choclate and coffee flavor.  A long bitter finish.  Milky mouthfeel.  There are no signs of the 8% alcohol stated above.
Nice beer.  Thanks Mike.

12 oz. bottle via trade with sliffy - Pours a thick dark brown color with a thin tan head that faded pretty quick.  No lacing.  Aroma is raosted malt, chocolate, and light esters.  Smells alot like a nice Imperial Stout.  Flavor is roasted malt, and light coffee and chocolate.  Palate is a little dry with a bitter finish.  Medium body.  I think this would make a better Baltic Porter than a Sweet Stout.  A nice beer.  Thanks Dan.

Bottle from Keg Liqour.  Poured a dark brown color with a large brown frothy head that lasted with good lacing. Medium complex toasted malty aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture. Medium roasted balanced flavor with a heavy roasted dark chocolate finish of long duration. This is a standout brew.

Thank you Skyview!  Black color with a thin head.  Strong aroma of chocolate and oats.  Solid taste of chocolate and Noble hops.  Dry finish.  Quite fine, even if it tastes nothing like a sweet stout.

Bottle shared with Hogtown Harry, biegaman, Blankboy, courtesy of blankboy.  Mild aroma - mild aroma - slight roast, chocolaty, very sweet.  Black, small brown head.  Taste - thin, sweet - more like a porter.  Dusty old stout.  Not too bad, tasty and interesting.

One of the best sweet stouts I have had anywhere.  I didnt know the abv was so high.  Lots of chocolate in the aroma and flavor.  Very light coffee and considerable malt with a subtle roasted character.

Very dark and thick in the glass with a one finger beige head. Aroma of milk chocolate, oatmeal and coffee. Full bodied. Taste mirrors the aroma, with rolled oats, roasty coffee and chocolate, and a kick of hops. One of the better Dark Horse stouts.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, tupalev & biegaman -- my bottle courtesy of lewis13. Pours a very dark brown with a small diminishing light-brown head. Aromas roasty and nutty along with some chocolate, oats and hops.  Flavour of oats, chocolate, light hops, some alcohol and a dry finish. Medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel. Not one of Dark Horses best but still pretty good.

Thanks to skyview for sharing!  A very impressive beginning to this series.  Lots of chocolate on the nose of this dark brown pour.  Hints of coffee in the thick body with a little chocolate in the finish.

Picked up a single 12-oz bottle at Rileys Wines of the World in Madison, WI. Pours an opaque near black brew with a rich creamy tan head. Excellent retention and lacing. Aroma has rich milk chocolate, dairy cream, roasted nuts, and espresso. Taste is smooth, creamy, and more honey nut flavor. Finish is creamy, chocolatey and a sweet aftertaste.

Bottle (12oz).  Shared with blankboy, biegaman and tupalev - blankboys bottle.  Looks like motor oil.  Oily, lush nutty deep roast malt aroma, slightly musty.  Bitter, oily slightly sour flavour - finishes with a touch of leafy, musty hops.  Mouthfeel is thick and creamy, lightly acidic, smooth finish.  Dry and complex - hides the alcohol well, but is ear-warming.

From a 12oz Bottle.  Purchased at Rileys Wines of the World in Madison, WI.  Pours a very dark black, chalky obsidian color with a thick layer of foamy bubbled tan head.  Well sustaining head that collapses onto itself to form a milky cream topping.  Lovely aroma thats brimming with coffee, dark chocolate, a touch of anise, and a hint of freshly chopped mint leaves.  Great balance of the roasty character with the minty hops, and as a bonus, the malt character is roasty and intriguing in other dark dimensions.  I love the balance between the hops, chocolate, and coffee; its what I would expect an andes mint melted in sumatran roast coffee would smell like.  Light bodied, crisply carbonated mouthfeel.  The mouthfeel is a bit thinner than Id like, and the flavors start out a bit slow, but they really take off on the back end.  The start of the palate brings out some weaker flavors of simple toast, but then transitions to an intense, long lasting flavor parade that brings out all of the great aroma traits.  The roastiness of the malt transitions into some smooth chocolate roast coffee, turns a bit spicy with the anise and licorice tones, and then finishes with some pleasant mint, all of the flavors lasting while the next phase builds on top of the former.  Great beer, but would be even better if it had a bit more body to create a silkier mouthfeel and get some of those flavors dancing in the carbonation to settle down on the tongue more quickly.

Pours a dark dark dark brown with no head.  This only makes it look darker, which in the world of stouts, makes me think a beer to be more attractive.  Maybe the bottle is old?  Doesnt smell old.  Mocha, coffee, chocolate, and everything in between.  Really reminds me of a slightly fainter Founders Breakfast Stout.  Creamy, with a little fig, and only a hint of roast and floral hops.  Dense and viscous in the mouth with surprising levels of carbonation given the complete lack of head.  Again, tastes a lot like Founders Breakfast Stout, though much cleaner in terms of diacetyl, though theres still some in there,but rightfully so.  Big sweet mocha maltiness.  Creamy, with a little hint of alcohol.  Chocolate, coffee, and some dates give way to a bit of balancing acidity.  Alcohol, roast, and a bit of astringency linger.  The aftertaste is mostly charcoally roast.  A rather nice beer indeed.

Big thanks to brewblackhole for forwarding this one.  Aroma reminds me of cocoa and some purple fruits.  Very smooth and creamy.  Taste is of chocolate again.  The finish is slightly roasted malty.  Sweetness stays with you with a coffee/chocolate residue.  Nice beer.

Bottle drunk on 4/21. Black with no head. Great mixture of dark roasted malts and oatmeal in the aroma. SMOOOTH and CREAMY body and taste. Some sweetness also. Sludge at the botton of glass. Very good beer.

12 oz bottle. Poured an opaque black color. Slid out of the bottle like a thick motor oil. Head was thick and tan with good retention and lacing. Aroma was of subdued dark chocolate. There was slight sweetness up front which was tempered by a roasty malt bitterness that lingered. The dominant flavors were coffee and roasted malt. Even though it wasnt aged in oak (as far as I know), there was an oaky note at the end. Solid stout.

Bottle sampled on 2/13/07 thanks to Silphium: Pours a mostly opaque dark brownish black with a thin ring of tan head.  Slightly caramely sweet dark malty aroma has some smoky notes and roasted coffee beans.  First sip is of lightly sweet and earthy dark malts with a touch of lingering dark chocolate and bitter roasted malt toward the finish.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2007 12 oz bottle VIA sliffy at Mystery Swap 2.0 (thanks man!). SHe is black black black in the black stout cliche with a nonexistsantential brown head...ie-she has no head!  She smells like an espresso and scotch. And tastes like it too with a nice chocolate finish. Body is medium, carbonation is..what carbonation?! ok, so i will nitro this bitch,,,,ummmm she takes it quite well...the tiny cascading bubbles compliment her in the most wondrous of ways./.. and she is silky then creamy then silky smooth, tasty smooth. Alas though she is far from prefect, as i had to mould her in such a silky image that she was not quite created in....Her body is originally only just ok, as was her taste. With my Nitro, she is a 5....but on her own she is only what she is...which is...nice....but far from what i want....

Bottle picked up by my pops on his recent trip to MI. Thanks Dad!  Pour was black with a tan head. Not so great head retention. Roasty, sweet oats, dark chocolate.  Dry, and slightly acidic mouthfeel.  A little bit of coffee in the finish (just how I like it). Mocha in a beer form. DH continues to impress.  High Five!!!

12oz - Aroma is rich roasted malts, cream, oatmeal and chocolate.  Pours black with a small brown head and good lacing.  Flavor is a match to aroma with roastiness all around.  Palate is creamy and dry.  Very tasty stuff.

Bottle.  Typical oatmeal stout aroma with significantly more chocolate than usual.  Light flowery hops under a nice thick roast and some chewy, earthy toffee.  Opaque black pour with a light brown head.  Strong roast taste with light acidity/sourness.  Slight sweetness from the oatmeal, and very faint berry.  Light tang on the very dry aftertaste, lingering roast and toast.  Body on the medium-side of full.  Lots of malt, swirling and thick with some ashy notes.  Very dry and smooth, with some coffee, nice!  Delicious!  Love this DH stout series - theyll probably all be tuned up to 4s on a re-rate.

Nice black body with small tan head.  Aroma of oats, cocoa, and roasted malts.  Flavor mostly roasted malt with hints of chocolate and coffee.  Alcohol is slightly apparent in the finish.  Overall a nice stout.

12 oz bottle courtesy of John.  Pours a thick pitch black color with a medium brownish beige head.  Aroma of dark roasted chocolaty malts and cocoa.  Taste is rich dark chocolate flavor with light hints of oats, barley and cocoa.  Excellent.

bottle - Pours black with a thin tan head.  The aroma is roasted malt and oats.  Roasted malts, oatmeal, and coffee comprise a tasty flavor thats well balanced by the hops that seem mild at first and lead into a moderately bitter finish.  Its full bodied and goes down with a nice, silky texture.  Again Im surprised by the 8% abv in a Dark Horse stout.  I wouldnt have guessed it.  Good beer.

Thanks to sliffy for this one.  Onyx pour with 1-finger tan head and a lot of floaties.  Roasty chocolate malt aroma, plus some molasses, chocoff, and nuts.  Tastes roasty chocolate malty, with molasses, chocoff, slight dark fruit as it warms, and a rich, dense, complex palate.  Stays somewhat dry.  Delicious.

Bottle from Silphium.  Pours a thick jet black color with a small mocha colored head.  Aroma is roasted malts and coffee.  These carry into the flavor with some dark chocolate notes.  Somewhat sweet at the start, followed up by some nice bitterness.  Nicely balanced.  smooth and creamy.  Tasty.

Thanks to Duane for the bottle. The body is perfectly black and thick with a ring of orangeish brown head. The aroma has lots of raisins and chocolate. There is also a little bit of pancakes and coffee. The taste has some strong coffee and milk chocolate notes. There is a nice smooth hint of roasted peanuts. The mouthfeel is thick and oily. Another great winner from Dark Horse.

Black as coal with a deep brown head.  Tiny bubbles.  Mediciney nose.  Creamy roasted flavor of day old wet campfire, burned bacon.  Oily.  Opens sweet, but deeply bitter overall, bitterness from strogly roasted malt, not from hops.
bottle...jet black pour with huge tan head intial taste is delicious burnt roastiness followed by a slighty sweet aftertaste

12 oz bottle courtesy of MI2CA, thanks Ted.  I really enjoy the DH stouts and this one pours just like the rest with the backest of black bodies and a small brown head that turns into a hairline thin lacing.  Aroma is light oatmeal sweetness and some charred roastiness.  The flavor is where the beer really takes off.  Starts off with an oily sweetness that comes in a roastiness and finishes with a beautiful strong bitterness to offset it all.  Leaves a lasting lightly roasted coffee bitter aftertaste.  A slightly below average carbonation to exentuate the medium bodied beer to create a nicely hefty feel on the cheeks.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Bottle.   Pours black with a tan colored head.   Aroma is floral hops, coffee, chocolate.   Flavor is roasted malts, vanilla, oatmeal, coffee, hints of peat.   Palate is full bodied, mildly carbonated, creamy, finishes on the bitter side.   Very solid stout.

Somewhat receding, creamy dark brown head, light tan colored lacing. Body is a thin looking very dark brown. Aroma is redolent with unexpected hoppiness, half grassy and half citric. Roastiness is plentiful. Scents of coffee, light chocolate and vanilla. Not much else. Flavor is so soft! roasty up front, simple, drawn out. Very creamy in mid-mouthfeel. Light hops now, followed closely by smoke, coffee, woodiness nearing the end of the sip. Finishes balanced and refined, a great recipe. Palate is somewhat creamy, moderately bitter. I absolutely adore the finish of this beer, so complex for brief moments, just marvelous!!!!

Pours thick and black with a gorgeous, tight mocha head.  Heavy coffee malt dominates the nose, which also notes dark chocolate and sweet cream.  The heaviness continues in the body, weighted by the oats.  Again, the heavily roasted malts throw lots of coffee and dark chocolate notes, leaving little room for subtlety.  Nice, albeit a bit one dimensional for such a big beer.

A solid beer. Nice oatmeal stout. Very smooth and easy to drink. Nothing out of the ordinary for a good stout. Plenty of chocolate and coffee aspects with a hint of oats. Light, bitter finish. Nice stuff, but nothing that will knock your socks off. Would be a good session stout, if not for the 8% which is barely detectable. Solid.

12 oz bottle, via moejuck.  Pours an oily black colored body under a very minimal dark brown head that vanished to a thin ring quickly.  Aroma is very roasty with lots of coffee, chocolate, and an oatmeal undertone.  Flavor hits you with roasted and burnt malts out of the gate, then fades to a licorice and coffee laced finish.  Lightly bitter hops on the finish also.  The body is quite thick and the oatmeal adds a nice creamy texture.  Moderate lightly fizzy carbonation level.  These guys just cant go wrong with a dark beer.  Very well rounded with an aggressive flavor.

Bottle thanks to Sliffy. Poured a thick black almost oil like body with big head settling to a nice foamy ring. Aroma is overpowered by the oatmeal but with a chocolate touch. Flavor is bittersweet. Malty with a sweet backbone. Slightly dry. Milk chocolate is present making it a pretty smooth stout. Pretty good.

this beer looks great. it pours thick black with a great dark brown head that slowly disappears to leave a great black hole looking beer with dark brown highlights from the remnants of the head. nice soft sweet milk chocolate mocha aroma. flavor sweet chocolate with acidic coffee notes. bitter dry slightly acidic coffee finish. medium body. thick silky smooth mouth feel. nice.

Black pour with a small brown head.  Smells of dark chocolate malts, roasted oats and a hint of coffee.  Strong chocolate flavor with bitter coffee, a hint  of brown sugar and toasted malts lingering for quite a while on the palate.  Medium-full oily body.

12oz bottle, courtesy of artusory.  Thanks, Ryan!  Pours a dark black center with very thin brown edges; medium tan head with fine bubbled lacing.  Plenty of charred and roasted malt in the aroma; smoke and bitter coffee.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: good density, viscous and chewy; loads of chocolate, roasted malts, and coffee; hints of smoke and marshmallow; lightly oily palate as well, very warming.  Long, bitter chocolate and roasted malt finish.  Very tasty, drinkable stout.
Thanks to Silphium for the bottle. Pours black with very little head. Aroma of sweet chocolate and coffee. Taste adds a lot of bitterness. Full body. Silky texture. Finishes clean.
Nothin I havent had before; interchangeable with many a sweet stout or porter out there -- which means "better than average," at least.  Movin onto the next beer . . .

Dark reddish brown body - very nice roasted vanilla and chocolately malts in the aroma that is also slightly alcoholic.  The flavor is pretty good too.  the roastiness really comes through - bitter coffee, and yes, even some oatmeal..  Not very sweet, which is good for me.  The finish is pleasantly clean and bitter.  An interesting and different take on the sweet stout, which is usually much lower in alcohol.

Bottle from Ughsmash (thanks!) - oily, black bodied pour, with a short-lived brown head - moderately sweet aroma, with notes of cream/milk, espresso, loads of grain - very grainy throughout the flavor - creamy sweetness tempered by a heavy roasted malt presence, complimented by bitterness coming late - medium-bodied and quite well-balanced - the alcohol is hidden well, but starts to become apparent in the finish - the mouthfeel isnt as creamy as I would like, but this is rather enjoyable.

Inky black pour with a substantial light brown head.  Sweetish cream aroma with some roasty in the background.  Oh wow!  Rich and creamy, silky with lots of velvet - they have not skimped on the oats here.  Nice amount of roasted flavor, not too sweet, with a fine bitterness intact.  This is a great stout!  Thanks Brad.

Bottled, most recent batch.  Poured deep brown with a short beige head that fizzled down quickly.  The aroma picked up heavy roasted oatmeal with milk chocolate...  very enticing and proved an excellent choice for dessert.  The flavor found about the same elements, with well-roasted milk chocolate, a hint of espresso, and a bunch of oats...  fairly grainy throughout on the palate, where I expected it to be smoother... did a ridiculously good job of hiding its alcohol... enjoyed the dry roasted chocolate that carried through the finish.  Very good brew.

Poured a clear very dark brown with a golden rim but no head.  A brown film was left on the glass with each swirl.  The aroma was very roasty with a fair amount of smoke and some chocolate notes.  Light phenols.  the flavor was on the short side.  Malty to start then just leaving a long roasted bitterness.  Light to medium body and a light creaminess.

12oz bottle, no date.  Pours motor oil black with a minimal tan head, though after agitating it does come up nicely for a bit.  Aroma of roasted malts and coffee, some oatmeal, a bit of paper oxidation, and char.  Flavor has the addition of some piney hops and dried raisins.  There is a bit of char again in the finish.  Alcohol is not noticeable.  Full body with soft carbonation--smooth!  Very nice beer.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Pours a deep dark brown - almost black - briefly capped by a thin brown head.   A ring of foam remains, providing nice lace.  Full rich aroma of roasted malt, burnt raisin, and a hint of cigar wrapper.  Good roasted malt flavor, sweet and also tangy, accompanied by plenty of bitter chocolate.  Lots of oily coffee in the finish, a bit of an ashy aftertaste.  Nearly full bodied, smooth carbonation.  A nice sipper.

From trade with Artusory. This is a very dark brown ale that pours with a thin tan head and a strong chocolate aroma. I cant really taste the oatmeal, since the chocolate and coffee flavors are overwhelming. The finish is slightly harsh and bitter but, overall, this is a pretty good stout.

Not as much creamy oat taste as I had hoped. More acidic and oily than most stouts. It has an inconsistency and unevenness that is hard to explain. None of the vinousness that most great stout have. A bit more enjoyable than the dark horse cream stout I tried recently.

Anticipated, but got little expected chocolate malt in the nose.  Pours truly black with rich tan small frothy head.  Disappears quickly.  Full chocolate malted taste with a slight bitter ending.  Very little frothyness on the tongue, but the right amount of syrupyness to reinforce its full flavor.  Nice warm mouth feel.  This beer disappears quickly without a bite at the bottom of the glass.  Nice pile of dead yeasties at the bottom of the glass testifies that this beer is unfiltered.  This is a fine satisfying stout.
Dark black pour creamier foam head. Almost a shot of espresso with barley and vanilla and licorice  injected. Very rich and a quick bitter sweet finish.
Poured a dark brown with a minimal tan head.  Aroma was of dark malt with a touch of sweet.  The flavor was malty, with a little chocolate and coffee thrown in.   Not bad at all.
Bottle: Black pour with a tiny tan head. Aroma, coffee, chocolate, and roasted malts. Flavor, oats, chocolate, a roasty bitterness. Medium bodied, smooth and sweet. Pretty solid brew.
Pours black, not much head.  Nothing special.  Not much oatmeal taste, not much aroma.  Average, except for alcohol content.

A pitch black beer with a slight brown shine underneath a dying brown head. The aroma is very lightly roasted. The flavor is sweet and very roasted malty combined with notes of oatmeal, and lighter notes of citrus, but also with a light acidity. Not that powerful a flavor - but good.

Sampled at Arg0s Pre-RBSG Tasting at his pad:
Dark black, brown head, spotty lacing. Nose of sharp roast and alcohol, light astringency, sweet chewy raisin. The flavor is chewy, lots of astringency, not much oat creaminess but explosive in intensity. Im usually not fond of things this unbrash, but it just did me up right. Good.
Looked better than it tasted, a real disappointment in the taste.  Thin consistancy with weak head, lacking flavor, indigestive finish...
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: Dark beer with root beer colored edges when held up to the light.  Lots of chocolate and roasted malt in the nose.  Very faint whispy head.  Very roasty taste that was almost like burnt toast.  Some chocolate, burnt coffee with some plum fruitiness.  Almost harsh on the tongue, especially for an oatmeal stout.

RBSG DC 2006: Deep brown-near black colored body with a small tan colored head.  The aroma is chocolate, toast, and light coffee.  Taste is roasted, bitter chocolate, cocoa, mocha, acidic roasted coffee, with some mild fruitiness in the background.
Quiet dark, almost black, minimal head. Grainy, light acidic aroma, mild roast. Nothing special. Medium bodied, dry roasted character with shallow end.

(12oz bottle, thanks artusory) Red-black body with minimal brown head.  Aroma is medium sweet, chocolate, some roast, light cherry, earthy/grapefruit.  Taste is medium sweet, chocolate, grapefruit, some roast, earthy.  Creamy medium body.

Bottle. Deep black with a small mocha ring of head. The aroma is pleasing to say the least - rich roastiness consisting of chocolate and toffee. The flavour has roasty bitterness, chocolate, toffee wafers, and as a result is quite tasty. Creamy mouthfeel and the alcohol is well masked. Nice stuff.
Coffee, chocolate and port aromas, black, small cappuccino head. Rich coffee and dark chocolate taste, bitter top to bottom. Terrific! Thanks mds.

Thanks to artusory. Deep brown body with light, swirling carbonation and an oily tan head. Aroma of deep-roasted marshmallow, dark chocolate, plums, and some noticeable alcohol. Sweet malt and oats initially, followed by substantial roast and hop bitterness. Nice, thick, complex sugars on the palate. A solid oatmeal stout overall.
Pours a dark caramel with no head.  Smells of burnt coffee, bitter sweet chocolate, and alcohol.  Tastes similar with lots of funky paper, fruit esters, and vegetables.  Mouthfeel is way too thin.

Up front this has a pretty sweet coffee and chocolate aroma.  Pull the glass back and theres a lot of alcohol.  Dark brown/black color with no head.  This has the thinnest body of any big stout Ive ever had.  Flavor is dark chocolate and coffee and a little alcohol.  Disappointing.

initially the aroma rocked, but then it was more and more alcoholic.  pretty imp stoutish at first.  taste comes on strong with alcohol but has no real depth.  kinda a lasting tackiness in the finish.

Bottle: Pours black, dark brown edges, thin brownish head, dies quickly, spotty lacing.   Soft lactose sweetness on the nose, subtle roasted malts, a touch of charred wood or campfire.   Very soft roasted malt tongue, slightly dry, minor bitterness, with an even softer lactose sweetness.   Fairly light, and not as sweet as others.   Definitely clean, but perhaps a bit more bitter and less sweet than what I am use to.   Body and mouthfeel are moderate, almost nearing the thin side in fact.   Decent, if a bit light.   Needs to be turned up a notch.   Very middle of the road in my opinion.   Thanks jtw for the bottle!

Dark but could be darker, heavy but could be heavier. Sweet with roasty bitterness and watery-coffee flavor underneath it all, a coffee flavor that could be stronger. Never thought Id say this about a beer, but it needs more of whats already in it.

Thanks to the DS crew for sharing this. Pours a dark brown, small dark tan head. Small dots of lace. Aroma is creamy and sweet, easy to smell and alluring, light coffee, chocolate, nips caramel candy (the coffee kind) Flavor is sweet chocolate oats, smooth easy to drink with an oily mouthfeel, and bitter finish. Tasty Stuff.

12oz bottle acquired in trade. Poured a dark black with an averaged sized brown head. Aromas of lactose, roasted malts, dark fruits, vanilla, caramel, and some nuts. Tastes of roast, dark fruits, chocolate, vanilla, and some nuts. Alcohol content well hidden (just a slight alcohol warming on the end). Medium bitter finish.

Bottle.  Another monster stout from these guys.  Pours black with a brown head that fades quickly into a film.  Burnt chocolate and heavy roasts dominate the nose along with hints of dark fruit.  Charcoal, heavy roasts, slight alcohol all intermingle throughout the taste.  Finishes with a good lingering bitterness.  Now I am going to have to start driving 3 hours to stock up.

This is a dangerous brew, smooth and easy to drink.  A black body under any light with a slender brown head.  An aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, dark brown sugar, and dried fruits demands a large swig, but roll it in the mouth and enjoy the creamy feel before doing so.  Added to the the mix in the taste are vanilla, bitter nuts, white peppers, and alcohol.  A very satisfying drink.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=1 to  RAYBOY01.<font size=-1>

Oily ebony pour with a deep tan head.  Very silky mouthfeel, that insinuates itself around the palate nicely. Chocolate/vanilla/molasses/brown sugar/and dates all rolling around in no particular order.  Nice hop bite in the lingering peppery alcoholic  finish.  Excellent.

Bottle thanks to Silphium.  Very dark pour with a decent head.  Large particals floating around in there.  Sweet aromas with chocolate and coffee.  Remained sweet on the tounge without too much bittering on the finish.  Pretty good indeed.  Thanks for another good one Brad!

Bottle.  Dark brown body under a thin tan head.  Viscous body that leaves a thin brown sheen.  Rasin/plum tartness over dark chocolate, coffee roast and tree sap aroma.  Lots of bright fruit (green apple) over milk chocolate and coffee bean in the flavor.  Acidic roast and green apple in the finish.  Id like this more if it had a sweeter lactose thing.

Nice dark pour... somewhat of a creamy dark tan head, but it goes away fast in the snifter. Nice staining on the glass. Smooth and creamy leathery roasted oatmeal malt aroma. Mmm... very nice creamy coffee and chocolate combination with some woody vanilla. Good stuff... Im curious about what went into this beer... obviously some roasted malt and oatmeal... any coffee or chocolate? Id like to think it is "natural", but who knows...  either way it is very nice and delicious... certainly up there with the Breakfast Stout.

Dark black pour w/ a thick brown nice looking head and some ok lacing.  Aroma is burn malts, semisweet chocolate, more roasted malts hints of a coffee and touches of vanilla.  Palate is thick and rich nicely creamy.  Flavor is mellow and lightly chocolaty not overly sweet some very light dry hop in the finish hints of coccoa and vanilla.  A pretty dang good stout.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2006 Aroma is burnt and toasty malts with hints of chocolate. Pours deep black with a diminishing dark brown/mocha head. Fore is sweet cocoa/chocolate/coffee with hints of vanilla and a nice smoothness from the oatmeal. Hints of dark fruits and a kick of hops in the finish. Very tasty brew.

Pour is black with with a nice dense dark brown head...smell is smell is sweet and toasty with chocolate and coffee...taste is sweet with cocoa and alcohol and a hint of coffee in the finish along with a sweet alcoholic note...
Pours black with a thin, fading, tan head. The aroma is smoke, chocolate, molases and plums. The flavor is burnt, smoke, raisins, molases and chocolate. The mouthfeel is soft and smooth.

Aroma of black patent malt with a roasted coffee and some chocolate notes.  Dark, dark brown with some light showing through right at the edges.  Roasty, dry flavor with lots of oatmeal and some chocolate that is very nice.  Medium-full body with a dry finish.  Thanks to Silphium for sharing this one.

Big thick pour, opaque and black in color with some cascading dark tan lace.  Bless this brewery.  Blackened oats, singed with love, elevate the aroma while burr grinded French roast coffee dust is sprinkled sporadically for extra character and complexity.  Rich bitter grinds strike heavy and fast for the flavor composite.  Hints of licorice flitter about, joining a waxy, ensconcing palate that bites off more than it should chew, and Ive got no problem taking down its regurgitation.  Black malts and far reaching bitterness celebrate the multi-dimensional intrigue of the tongue.  Loving it as always.  Thanks so much for bringing this along, Silphium!

Thanks Brad!  Pours to a darky brown/black body with a thin tan head.  The aroma is roasty and sweet with oatmeal and chocolate/coffee.  The flavor is rich and roasty.  Dry, yet sweet.  Nice roastyness.  The palate is dry and roasty.  Lightly sweet.  Medium-full body.  Quite a good brew.

Thanks Sully!  Pours a black color with a small off white head that has an almost reddish tinge to it.  Aroma is rich and roasty w/ alcohol and chocolate/coffee hints.  Flavor is very roasty and rich with hints of oatmeal in the aftertaste.  Overall a enjoyable stout.

12 oz. bottle from Walleye in a recent trade - thanks Jim.  I thought I was pouring used motor oil out of the bottle.  Just dont remember seeing an oatmeal st. this thick & black!  aroma of dark roast malt and some bittersweet chocolate.  flavors are more of the same with coffee, hints of anise and a fairly strong hop backbone.  somewhat buttery with a lingering yet pleasant dry bitter finish.  I dont think there is much middle ground on this beer, either youll like it or you wont.  I like it!!!

from the bottle. the last of the 3 stouts that I bought and this one did not disappoint me. poured black with  a brown head with some lacing. flavor sweet, malts, chocolate, coffee. flavor the chocolate and malts where right on for me got some dark fruits and berries. very good.

Pours with a black body topped by a medium thick, brown head with some lacing.  Its sweet, malty and roasty with a nice chocolate and coffee note.  Very nice.  A slight hoppiness underlays the dominent flavors.  Full bodied, smooth and a touch warming.

12 oz bottle via trade with SuIIy - Thanks Mike! - Pours very black with a nice creamy mocha head that stays for a bit and laces down the glass. Aroma is roasted malts, rich milk chocolate, a bit of plum.  Flavor is roasted malts, some of that chocolate but more of dark chocolate, some coffee as well.  Nice bitter hop finish.  Palate is smooth creamy and full bodied.  Very pleasant mouthfeel.  This is a very nice stout!

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2007 another excellent stout from dark horse...black body with minimal reddish brown head...aroma of roasted malts, heavy in chocolate and cocoa...taste is heavy in dark bitter chocolate, cocoa, some faint hops...nice and creamy palate...simply one of the best oatmeal stouts out there...darker than hell!

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a light tan head. Head is VERY fizzy and has a redish hue to it. nose is big roast, oats, chocolate. Taste is big chocolate malt, some ligh thopps and a big bitter finish. A nice roast is also present and it almost seems to choke you due to the filmy coating on around your mouth.

Roasty, coffee-like, chocolate, sweet aroma hides notes of berries.  Opaque black body is topped by low, off-white head that recedes to ring.  Roasted malts, berries and herbal hops play off each other nicely in the flavour with fair finishing, roasty bitterness.  Medium body with moderate carbonation that fills the mouth.  Sampled at the Michigan Brewers Guild Summer Beer Festival 2005.
12 oz bottle. Rick black with a tan head. Aroma is rich and full of cocoa, oats, coffee and chocolate. The body is very rich and smooth with a nice, dry finish. Another fin beer by Dark Horse.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2007 Bottle from Eyedrinkale shared on 8/5/05.  Pours a dark blackish-brown with an initially large tan-coffee colored head that quickly dissipates to just a smattering of bubbles on top and at the edges.  Really heavily sedimented beer with plenty left in the bottle.  Aroma smells of dry roast, black coffee, vinousness and some sweet toffee, but not much of it.  Dark, bitter cocoa beans and a earthy, ashy sort of aspect too.  Flavor didnt work out on this bottle, not sure why, I know it was cellared properly.  But regardless, it was thin, wet and at the same time ashy and astringent.  Like an old pot of black coffee.  Grapey, muddy, loose, watery, astringent, charred.  Not many nice things to say about this one.  Seemed like an older bottle, no green hops flavor.  Maybe this batch just didnt age well.  Oh well, no big deal, Ill try a fresh one soon, and redo it.Rerate.Still dont know how old the bottle, but the head retention is still poor.Muted aroma of cherries, chocolate and vanilla.  Nothing particular.  But the flavor is full of roasted malts and lovely chocolatey notes.  A slight nutty/bready edge but its overcome by some phenolic and char character.  Hmm, actually, thats not such a good thing.  Texture is perfect as always from DH, but the grain bill just seems weird.  Ill up it a few points, I guess, its still pretty drinkable, just too many phenols and not enough residual sugar.

Sampled draught at the Michigan Brewers Fest.  Totally black and thick with a thin ring of very dark head...beautiful milk-chocolaty nose, very much like a candy bar, with light hints of fruit (perhaps blueberries or raspberries) and smokiness...body is milky-sweet at the front, coffee roastiness comes in later to disturb and challenge the sugars, hints of fruit abound and the mouthfeel makes for eminient drinkability.  These guys are great, I wish they hadnt sold out of everything else!

Almost black, ring of dark beige head. Excellent smoky and highlky roasted nose. Complex coffeeish graininess unifies the malts with the greenish hops that guard over any excessive sweetness. Campfire is the first word that comes to mind when sipping. Great balance of cigary roastiness, dark berries, greenish hops and lasting bitterness. Id only prefer if this slight tart bite would not show uip. Medium body, very comfortable carbonation. Another great stout from Dark Horse.
Pours black with a thin rind of brown around the rim of the glass.  Smells of sugar and oatmeal.  Tastes of chocolate, nuts and coffee with a dark chocolate finish.

Aroma:  burnt malts, semi-sweet chocolate, slight fishiness, some charred wood, and some grains

Appearance:  very dark brown-->black in color, tan head, some lacing

Flavor:  sweet hops, semi-sweet chocolate, some grapes, smokiness, molasses, and some cream

Palate:  very smooth, rich, smokey and semi-sweet chocolate aftertaste

Black black black with a deep brown head.  Rich creamy nose of oatmeal, milk, grains, and smoky rich chocolate with a little black "imperial-ness" noted.  Flavor is very sweet, very well developed with contrasting sharp smoky wood flavors that bite at the mouth and a more subtle and smooth creamy oatmeal flavor.  This beer rivals Shakespear as one of the best sweet flavored stouts I know of.  Big thanks to wohlfs for sending the bottle.

Thanks to Styles for this one.This thing is ebony with a rich creamy tan head.Man,the whaft of roasted malts is crazy.Chocolate and expresso goodness.This is a damn fine tasting brew:the dark rich taste of chocolate and expresso are fantastic.Great brew.Thick and chewy on the tongue.

Bottle... Pitch black with a small, creamy, orange/brown head. Good retention. The nose is rich with milk chocolate, heavy cream and lightly roasted cashews. Lots of sweet chocolate, espresso, and honey-glazed nuts in the flavor. Medium-bodied and very creamy with mild carbonation. Short, bitter-sweet finish... more sweet than bitter. Very good oatmeal stout. Thanks to eyedrinkale for the bottle!

The dark appearance, the scent of the oatmeal, chicory, and boozy. Bit of metallic and sourness, not all that smooth, as bitter cocoa powder grains, however quaffable. Cream, malt, coffee, good not outstanding.Thanks for fulfilling my requests Wohlfs

Very dark black oily pour. Nice rocky brown head. The aroma is quite choclately, very dessert like. Roasted nuttiness and some alcohol also develop. The flavor is packed with stoutie goodness. Roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, medium bitter. Medium body with a lightly alcoholic finish. Some of hte bitterness somes from the malts and some from the hops. These guys know how to make stouts. Another Dark Horse winner.

Definitely opaque black liquid, topped with a small head of brown bubbles. Actually a 4.5 but ill give it a four in appearance. Light coffee and german chocolate (almost black forest cake) in the aroma, with some toasty grain and alcohol. Rich and creamy in feel. Fairly mild in the flavor department, something that isnt always a bad thing. Stronger roast start followed by mild coffee and chocolate. Flavors thin toward the end with some paler malt and a touch of black malt coming out. Dry finish. Not a sweet stout, not a dry stout, just a stout.
Black color with a large dark brown head. Rich roasty malt, chocolate, and plum aroma and flavors. Very creamy feel. Very good!

Pitch black color with a generous light brown head. The aroma was full of wonderful roasty, toasty coffeish chocolaty tones...some prune tones as well. The flavor was not quite as full, but nice...chocolate coffee...prunes...roastiness in the aftertaste. Smooth, silky, creamy feel...wet, coating finish. Very nice sweet stout. Thanks Wohlfs!

Bottle. Thanks to wohlfs for the trade! Pours opaque black with a small dark brown head. Nose is coffee, roasted malt, and cocoa. Taste is coffee, roasted malt and light grains and chocolate. Very little sweetness in this, in my opinion. The smoked stout they make seemed sweeter. Body is slightly oily and has light bitterness. Finish is more roasted malt, faint fruit, coffee, light chocolate and a hint of molasses.
Black with brown film for a head. Big coffee aroma. All coffee flavor. Full bodied oily mouthfeel. Where is the oatmeal though?

surprisingly roasty for a sweet stout.  i expected more oatmeal presence.  pours an oily near-opaque-black.  small bright tan head.  slightly too tangy/bitter for a stout (particularly a sweet stout) but its good as it is.  plan to follow it with their #2, the cream stout.

Bottle:  Aroma is of coffee, fruit, and chocolate malt.  Pours dark brown, virtually black, with small tan head.   Flavor is roasted coffee and light malted chocolate.  Some burnt flavors in the finish with a nice balance of light maltiness and hops.  Light sourness.

Bottle.  Deepest black color.  Very thick appearing on the pour.  No head, carbonation is minimal in this beer.  Aromas of deeply roasted grains, coffee.  Very smooth and silky mouthfeel.  Full bodied.  Flavor is burnt grain, almost astringent,  highly roasted coffee beans.  Hops kick in at the finish to dry and pucker you up a little.  Well done.  I liked this in spite of the apparent lack of carbonation.

Bottle from the very odd store located next to the brewery: Pitch black, coffee brown around the edges, thin chocolate milk-looking head.  Bean (as in coffee and vanilla) nose. Body magically thickens in my mouth, like its cascading upon swallow. Huge burst of espresso right away, dry, chalky espresso and slowly softens to a slightly fruity hint with generous hopping obvious.  Leaves a nice oily, burnt coffee taste that coats all parts of my mouth. These guys are serious about their stouts. The "One" is a perfect start  at the brewpub, go look at all the cool stuff attached to the wall, and the hilarious graffitti in the bathrooms!
good nose thats rich with chocolate, dark brown body with creamy tan head,  yeasty sweet flavor, bitter hop finish, this brewery needs some serious help with their labels, this is outrageous.

Impenetrable black. Quarter-inch cappuccino foam ring surrounds the broken caramel foam. Seductive nose of blackberries, vanilla bean, and rich espresso. Mild fruity hop presence meshes with bittersweet chocolate, honey, candied black currants, and tar undertones. Full and creamy mouthfeel. Silky, semi-oily. Starts with full-blown espresso richness infused with black licorice. Assertive char flavors grit up the palate and contribute to the roasted barley dryness. Vanilla accentuates the firm toasted wood flavors. Very fulfilling, throughout, with a rich interplay between the black patent astringency and roasted barley. Just enough espresso to curtail the chalkiness. Finishes everlastingly chewy and burnt with a steadily heightening espresso richness that reaches its apex in the finish amid bittersweet chocolate assertions and dark fruit nuances. Delicious. Note: This is a very fragile brew and seems to go sour rather quickly. My bottle was thoroughly rich, completely devoid of sourness and oxidation, which seemed to be the case with previous samples.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Black brew that sits under a thick tan head. Nice roasted nose. first impression on tasting is a slight sourness. Get past that and you find some chocolate notes.Finishes clean.
slight lactic sourness, thin body, average oatmeal stout. This is ok, but not special. thx for hopsrus for sending it this w

Decent stout.  Dark black color, little if any head.  Aroma is roasted, malty sweet and somewhat alcoholic.  Flavor is pleasant mix of coffee and sweetness.  Some smoked flavors creep in there too.  Moderate to thin body.  Sweet lip smacking finish.

The beer as its ejects from the 12 ounce brown bottle pours a pitch-black, the head portly in size, the texture spumous, and the lace a fine curtain to conceal the glass. Nose is that of toasted grain, sweet chocolate, fresh and pleasant to the senses, start is sweet, nice malt profile, the top middling in feel. Finish has a spirited acidity, the hops delightful, dry and lingering aftertaste, drinkable stout tis true.

Super black and a thin dark brown head.  "Dark smelling" beer.  Roasted malts, and coffee, and chocolate, also I think I detected some cereal notes in there as well, like Cheerios.  Hoppy inital flavor, then the bitterness of roasted coffee which continued thought the finish.  This brewery is fast becoming a favorite of mine.

This beer formed a small sized light brown head that was creamy and smooth with fine-medium sized bubbles that fully diminished. The body was black and opaque with no carbonation observed. The nose was malty, chocolate and coffee. The flavor was chocolate and coffee that left an aftertaste. The mouthfeel was smooth and the lacing was very sparse.

This brew poured a very large head, for a stout, of fine to medium sized dark brown colored long lasting bubbles that left behind a fair lace.  The body is pitch black in color with no visible carbonation.  The aroma is a nice dark malty one with mollasses tones and roasted notes.  The mouth feel is initially hoppy with a smooth malty taste and a lingering coffee finish that is a little bitter.  All-in-all a nice stout that is a horse of a different color!

Beautiful tar black with nice tan head now escaped to the edges. Some lacing. smell chocolate, coffee, smoke?, definite burnt characteristics. Great burnt marshmallow flavor leading to a deep coffee bean bitterness in the finish. Smooth beer. Apple peel in the flavor as well. Nice hoppiness. This is the One Oatmeal Stout Ale for those of you reading that may not know. Too is actually the Cream Stout. Enjoy.

Deep brown hue with tan creamy head and good lace. The aroma is toasted and burnt dark malts, fruity, mocha, coffee, and aromatic hops. The taste didn't match the nose. Starts sweet and oatmeal like but quickly fades to a light coffee and hop bitterness with a hint of smoke and apple. Some good qualities but seems muddled and not refined. The mouthfeel was surprising. It's weak, thin, and watery. Chalky feel too. Just didn't make it, starts great but got lost somehow. Maybe a bad bottle?
sweet oaty aroma, thin brown head with nice lace, weak body, super sweet with berrylike flavors and a dry hoppy finish unbefitting of a stout

Mild nose of chocolate, roasted barley, light oats.  Dark black with a light brown small head, just whisps on top and some small lace really.   Light chocolate with some lighter malts comming through.  Some roasted flavors, moderate malt bitterness. Hops lurk a ways underneath and are quite accidic and bitter once found.  Mild oats are balanced, body has a bunch of holes in it.  Lingering sweetness.

Coal black color,small black head that lasted for a short time.Sweet malty aroma,lightly fruity and hoppy.The taste is sweet and malty with a nice hop presence coming through,light coffe chocolate tones but over all very smooth and drinkable.The after taste is chocolate and malty with a decent hop tone to it.Very nice brew and even better trade,thnaks PsychProf for another fine brew.

Deep, oily brown-black colour with a tiny coffee & cream head. Sweet, nutty roastiness in the nose. Full mouthfeel, very creamy. Roasted malt flavour with the expected hints of chocolate, coffee and caramel, and a mild hop finish. Not a world-beater, but a very solid stout.

(Also known as "One")Strong roasted aroma emanates from another dark, motor-oil like body.  Flavor is smooth, somewhat dry, dominated by roasted malts and with a slightly bitter aftertaste.  Not as interesting as the Cream Stout, but still solid.

Not a fan of stouts. This one had a molasses look to it when it came out of the bottle.  Complex smells to it, a sweet roasted smell.  First taste tasted of strong coffee.  Finished this one with a slow deliberate pace tring to pace the taste.  After tasting this one, would recommend it to someone looking for a good stout.  (thanks psychprof for giving me the opportunity to rate this one.)

On my bottle it says Oatmeal Stout Ale and One so there seems to be some confusion going on as to which stout is 1 or 2, but thats fine. This is typical Dark Horse for me by now; quite solid roastiness, almost over the edge, just a tiny bit of sweetness conveyed by the flaked oats, pretty full in the mouth, clever hop close. Just another good stout by them. Not a world-killer, but tasty.

text: Im not a fan - blistering roasts and bitters and roughness in the mouth when I like my stouts full and chewy and sweeter.  Obviously of good quality ingredients, just not to my taste.

Also known as "Too" in the trio of Dark Horse stouts.  This one and the Cream variety look remarkably similar - deep brown with a quick scattering tan head.  This one has less of a nose and a more unbalanced flavour and texture.  Its more unevenly carbonated and its harder to find the either the dark malt goodnesss or lighter oaty tones under the edges. In fact, its best to mix the two stouts.  Im serious!  I had the two pints poured simultaneously and when each got down to a third of a glass or so I whimsically mixed them.  The result deepened the full round sweet flavours and allowed them to better battle the bitters.  The mixture reminded me of some of the better Imperials for complexity.
A nice stout deep dark brown color, aroma of roasted chocolate malt, roasted malt taste with hints of chocolate and caramel, wonderful mouthfeel,hop bitterness comes through nicely in the end, nice
